reviewText:
I thought this game was relatively average until now. (Average is different from bad!)
Then there was conquest ending, and the game went from average, to absolute masterpiece.
I fully recommend this title for that ending alone. Truly an experience unlike any other.

Disclaimer: Conquest ending may not be suitable for the faint of heart. It may cost you a night's sleep, or your dignity, or your manliness, or whatever. Consult your doctor to see if conquest is suitable for you.


SUPER Lengthy version to sell you on Conquest End:
I'm going to great lengths to sound as ambiguous as possible and avoid spoilers. So if it sounds weird and the phrasing is strange, it's likely intentional. Or me being stupid.

I felt like for the most part the game was playing out like a standard JRPG, gather a party, go beat up a bad guy and save the day for the most part. Which made it average, but not great (mostly due to the large amount of AAA games that already use this formula over and over). The interesting character to character interactions and quips felt like they were cut in favour of the darker overtone and the story focus.

This brings us to the subject of the conquest ending. The darkest and edgiest of endings in a darker and edgier sequel.
So in conquest, the world once again needs saving, but now there's a great cost that one must pay to save the world. In most games, this generally means the thousands of faceless enemy mook that you killed to get there, or whatever. Not this time. A hefty price must be paid, as the characters are put in a situation where there are no winners. One of them must walk the path and suffer a fate worse than death. This is the incredible weight of emotional baggage involved in this tear-jerking emotional experience. The guilt from walking the path just to prevent the end of the world. Due to the setting, it tells a tale of a highly relatable, but painfully tragic story. (This is probably the reason why it's also regarded as the most traumatic ending. Its simply our reaction to knowing that you never want to be put in a position like that ever in real life.)

Conquest is essentially a downer ending. But a very well executed one. Frequently there are shows, movies or stories with downer endings that just feel like a cheap cliffhanger or a and then everyone died the end". Conquest sets itself apart by being different. There's resolution
date: but is it the one you expect? There's peace to the world at last
recommended: but will it hold? The world was saved
hoursPlayed: but does the end justify the means to do it? The beauty of the writing slowly opens up to you the further you get.\n\nConquest is though invoking. It makes you really think about the things we often take for granted or simply take at face value. What is saving the world? How tangible is saving the world? Does the world matter enough for you to go to ANY length to save it? Would you rather let the world end and enjoy the remainder of it with your friends? Why did you choose this path for the world? To prevent others from doing it? Or to ensure your own survival? Who's the real villian here? If you've lost everything you hold dear
voteText: does saving the world even matter anymore? The boundaries of gray morality and ethics are pushed in this ending to further make us question what's really going on.\n\nConquest is a masterpiece
helpfulPercent: a work of art
votesHelpful: and a gaming experience like no other. It has changed my opinion on this game
votesTotal: and has shown that is far from mediocre. For an excellent game ending that's different and puches you hard in the gut
votesFunny: you simply have to experience the conquest ending of HDN:RB2.\n\n(Disclaimer: There are many games that are similar in certain
commentsCount: highly specific ways
column16: and or may be better in some aspects. Your mileage will vary
column17: discretion advised.)"

reviewText:
Well, the second Neptunia game for PC has finally been released. And, as IFI's second PC port, I think they did a better job in terms of basics like optimization and even graphics.

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 2 is, much like Re;birth 1, a remake of the second game in the series, Mk2. Normally, RPGs nowadays require a run of the first game to understand some of the plot details without spoiling the first game, but because the first game for the PS3 was so bad, IF and CH decided to reboot the entire series, so Mk2/Re;birth 2 is actually the first canonical game in the franchise.

Gameplay:

If you're familiar with the first Re;birth game, you'll feel right at home with the standard battle mechanics. You first do a basic attack, and then have up to 3 extra attacks with varying mechanics on their own. You have Rush, which deals multiple hits and is helpful for increasing your EXE Drive. Power is the heavy hitters of your standard attacks, and Break deals tons of damage to your Enemies Guard bar. When an enemies guard is broken (A Guard Break), they take more damage until your turns are up and they attack again. Partners still give you special attacks if your EXE Drive gauge is at or above the required amount along with their Lily Ranks. You also have Special Attacks that use up your SP. These attacks range from doing a good amount of damage, healing your allies, or Support by either raising your own and/or your allies stats temporarily or lowering your foes stats. Finally, EXE Drives are your Super Moves. They deal tons of damage but you need to unlock them through the Story, level ups, or Events on the World Map via Chirper in the city menus and require 1 or more level of the EXE Gauge to be filled. You have 2 different types of EXE Drives: One that requires just the character using it and one that requires 2 or more characters who are partnered or out in battle along with everyone else as well as a specific Lily Rank number. New to Re;birth 2 is the fact that you now have 4 characters out on the field, giving you more options to bring the pain to your foes. Dungeons and the World Map are still the same, but Re;birth 2 was not built with the Jump button in mind. This makes the dungeons pretty linear and kinda boring, like Final Fantasy 13, but the battle system is still solid.

Finally, a new addition to the game is Stella's Dungeon. It's a real time, Mystery Dungeon/Spelunker-like mini-quest of sorts that involves the personificiations of the remake's developer, Felistella, going through the dungeons you've unlocked via Plans or Story. You choose a dungeon, how many floors, equip Stella with a Weapon and Armor and Felis with an Orb and Cat Necklace to increase your stats before sending them off. They always start at Level 1 once you send them out, and they'll either fail or succeed after a certain amount of real time. Succeeding gives you new items, plans, and other goodies. Failing, much like Mystery Dungeon or Spelunker, results in all of your equipment you equipped for that dungeon to be lost. I cannot stress this enough: BUY THE HISTY'S RESCUE PLAN DLC! It makes Stella's Dungeon MUCH less annoying as, once you activiate the plans given through this DLC, halves the amount of time a dungeon requires and lets you keep all your equipment if you fail,

If you haven't played a Neptunia game since Mk2, the AP system is gone, meaning you don't have to think too much about what your next plan will be. I admit that I actually miss the AP mechanic as, while it did cause some rage from some pretty difficult fights, it made you think a bit more on what attacks and items to use at a given time. The battle system is fine as is, especially with Re;birth 3 adding more options, but the AP system added a bit more strategy to the battles. Otherwise, everything is the same.

Story:

Let's be honest, you're not really playing Neptunia for a gripping" storyline. The story here
recommended: is not as good as Re;birth 1 and not even close to Victory/Re;birth 3 or even V2 on the PS4. The Goddesses have been defeated by the leader of the Four Felons

reviewText:
I think the mistake that most people make is comparing this small-scale niche RPG to grand AAA JRPGS ( FF and the like ) so the difference in execution is something to keep in mind.

I was like that initially, but after reminding myself that it's not meant to be one ( when i was playing Re;birth 1 ) - I found myself enjoying it a lot more.

STORY

CPUs have been defeated and captured; nobody has a flipping clue about what lead to this in the past three years. Your job is to become stronger to beat up the baddies in order to restore the state of the world.

In concept, it's a parody and satire of the gaming industry and it's history. Nothing too much about ideals and higher cause -- and it constantly reminds you of it with cheeky jokes and wall-breaking interactions. Not as many jokes as Re;birth 1 so far solely due to the absence of Nep, but Red does a decent job as her replacement for a comical character.

So it's not all about the loli fantasy harem that naysayers claim it to be ( there will inevitable a bit of that, but it's within reasonable doses ;p)

GAMEPLAY

Exactly the same as Re;birth 1, but now with four characters in combat.
They've done a much better job with balancing difficulty curves early on in the game and considerably lessened the need for a grind.
Your party gets useful, but balanced skills much earlier in the game to help you out with the boss encounters without needing to outlevel them by a huge margin or coming back with overpowered gear.

e.g Red gets an AoE STR buff before level 18 , Compa gets paralysis removal and AoE heal before level 18 as well

Therefore, the pace of the game feels a lot better than the previous game - even if it feels so much easier than the first game.

GAMEPLAY PT2

This part concerns Maps and Stella's dungeon minigame

Maps aren't atrocious as the Re;birth 1 with clear-cut paths to the event sign. They now have branching paths that encourage you to go to all ends to look for that loot.

Unfortunately they made a deliberate decision to remove maps with elevation - the only sole purpose for jumping in a technical context.

it could still be a lot more complex, but it's a considerable improvement.

Stella's Dungeon is a new minigame where you send off a cute little girl into a dungeon for your own benefit (*cough* Recettear)

It works in real-time and she will go through the various floors of the dungeons you've explored in hopes of getting progressively stronger gear for herself and loot for you.

A fun mini-game to initiate while nepgear and her friends wander off into a dungeon.


SOUND

Very catchy new overworld music - better than Re;birth 1. New battle themes are also quite refreshing and in-line with the game.

One of the issues that I had was Nepgear's voice being muffled during special attacks (mirage dance, etc) and in certain cutscenes.

Another is the unbalanced audio volume. The overworld theme is overpowering everything else in the game when you're out there. It will drop in volume whenever a character idles and starts errant chatter, but in general it is still too loud


so far for $14.50 , it's a steal for this cute game

have a nepping good time ~

reviewText:
Short overview of QoL changes from Re;birth1 to Re;birth2, for those who have played the previous game and are interested:

- More maps. The maps still get recycled (and the new forest map is just a retexture of the snowfield map), but less often.
- Idea chips aren't as frustrating to get - they don't appear in hidden treasures anymore, every harvest point now has 1 regular item affected by harvest shift, and 1 idea chip unaffected by harvest shift.
- 4 characters in party, finally allowing you to use all 4 CPU's/Candidates in your team.
- You get some free Lily ranks from Chirper events, alleviating the grind a little.
- HDD activation cutscenes are faster (Plutia isn't in the game though, that helps this one a lot)
- Characters feel more useful overall - Re;birth1 had the major issue of introducing a lot of Maker characters after you already got all the CPU's, making them relatively weak. Other way around in this game. Cave best girl <3
- Difficulty curve is better, there's no real spike early on like that accursed Noire fight from Re;birth1 (you know the one)

Probably a lot of other stuff I forgot, this was just off the top of my head. As someone who loved Re;birth1, I think they did a great job with this game as well. If you enjoyed Re;birth1, definitely pick this up!

To be honest, I think the first game is A LOT better than this one.
The characters are still wonderfully quirky, and their designs are still cute, too, which is nice.

There are sooo many chirpers, though, which really got on my nerves. It's a lot of interactions between segments of gameplay which can't be ignored either because some chirpers give out plans.

Also, there are HUGE issues with the game crashing and being unplayable (something that I don't think Idea Factory has fixed yet?). So it was definitely frustrating combing through all the forums and trying out all the different fixes. I think it was worth it though, because I really do enjoy and love the Hyperdimension series.

reviewText:
Are you ready for a super cute, fairly challenging JRPG packed with cliches, bad jokes and pop culture references? No? Then F&!$ off.

Using an identical system to Re;Birth1, navigating this game will be like riding a bicycle if you've played any other Hypdimension Neptunia game. The combat, lily rank, remake and game dev systems are identical. If you haven't, it'll be pretty easy to pick up. Join CPU Candidate Nepgear on her journey to rescue the CPUs, and save Gamindustri once again from the evils of game piracy, low shares and ultimate destruction!

Admittedly, Nepgear is nowhere near as likeable as Neptune. She has probably the most unimaginative and cliched personality they could (not) think of. But making returning appearances are all of the developer characters, with the same endearing (and annoying) personalities, delivering the same hit and miss humour as before. Overall, the story and characters have passable writing and decent pacing, even if it is nothing new and has definitely been done before. Most notably in its prequel. But who doesn't like a game in which a SEGA takes (extremely valid) potshots at the PlayStation, XBOX and Wii?

But let's get down to the actual bad. This is a functional PC port, but it has problems and lots of them. Where Re;Birth1 ran like hot butter for me, Re;Birth2 had problems right from the off. Memory leaks, unreliable framerates, occasional UI lockups, screen tearing, buggy text wrapping and eventual crashes that sometimes required the task manager to shut down plague the port. I was able to complete the game with these issues, as none of them actually managed to break the game. But it was at times aggravating, nonetheless.

Ultimately, I'm giving it a 7 out of 10. It's a good JRPG, for those that are interested in the genre and don't mind a completely female cast. Without the technical issues I would give it a 7.5, maybe an 8. Hopefully Idea Factory, Compile Heart, and Felistella do something about these issues in future patches.

reviewText:
I will try to make this review as compact as possible, so similarly to my review of Re;Birth1, I will not go over the story as it will make the review unnecessarily long. First of all, I have only played a little bit of Mk2, which is what this game is a remake of, so I can unfortunately not point out any smaller differences between the games. Despite my playtime here I have played Re;Birth2 quite extensively on Vita previously however. Regardless, what I do know is that:
Dialogue between characters are now 2D animated portraits instead of 3D models, like they are in Re;Birth1.
Some playable characters are gone and replaced with others. More specifically, Nisa and Gust are both replaced with the Oracles of each continent.
We get another ending.
And I believe that’s about it for the major new features. If you’ve already played Re;Birth1, you will have a fairly good idea of what to expect from this game. So, let’s start with the actual review. Like I mentioned, the game plays out extremely similarly to Re;Birth1. When I say that, I am referring the overworld navigation, similar menus and design layout. The Remake System, which lets you tinker with the enemies and items of dungeons, is also here. While not necessarily a bad thing that stuff are similar, some might be let down by the lack of changes.

Combat also plays out the same way, with you having three different customizable styles of combos (Rush, for building the EXE gauge, Power, for doing raw damage, and Break, for taking down shields). As I mentioned Rush, that also means that the EXE gauge, which lets you fire off cool looking ultimates at enemies is also here. The main difference is that you can now have four characters on the field at a time instead of three, with four more as support, which is a welcome addition.
Also, (for me at least) there aren’t any major difficulty spikes in Re;Birth2. I know the majority of you who played Re;Birth1 got obliterated by Black Heart in Chapter 2. I can say that I did, no shame admitting it. After all, the game did a bad job at explaining the necessity of grinding. Thankfully, Re;Birth2 is much less grindy, and has a much friendlier difficulty curve.
That’s not to say you won’t have to grind however, you will simply have to do it less.

Judging by what I’ve written up until now, the game is seemingly a straight up improvement over Re;Birth1. I wish I could agree with that, however that is not the case. The writing, which most of you probably liked the most in Re;Birth1, is a bit lackluster. Don’t get me wrong, it’s not bad by any means, it’s just… Not of the same quality. The better jokes are few and far between, and without the original four goddesses for the most part of the story things start to derail a little. In the next game in the series, Victory, which we will get a remake of under the name Re;Birth3 in fall, there is even a running gag in how people didn’t take to Nepgear as a main character.
Personally, I have nothing against Nepgear, Uni, Rom and Ram. In fact, I like them very much as individual characters. It’s just that the fourth-wall-breaking-comedy is for the most part gone and the writing as a whole comes off a bit flat at times. It’s not a deal breaker by any means, but it’s worth keeping in mind.

One of my favorite new features is Stella. She is a cute little girl which is the main character of a small minigame called “Stella’s Dungeon” which plays out in real time. Here, you are able to assign Stella to explore previous dungeons you’ve beaten. If she succeeds, she will get rewards for your party and earn better equipment for herself, which will help her explore deeper dungeon levels. On the other hand, if she is defeated, she will lose everything she’s earned up to that point.
While it’s a minor addition, I adored it personally and I hope that it’ll make an appearance again in future titles.

With all that said, I can definitely recommend this game if you’re a fan of anime and JRPG’s in general. However, if you haven’t played Re;Birth1 yet, do yourself a favor and play that beforehand.
Sure, levels can also feel a bit bland, and the game plays out for the most part just like Re;Birth1 did. However, if we put it into this perspective: If you liked Re;Birth1, I can guarantee that you will also enjoy this game. With a return of our beloved 2D portraits, the Victory battle system and 1080p, this is in my opinion truly the best way to experience Hyperdimension Neptunia Mk2.

reviewText:
When a sequel is released, there are a couple of different options you can take.  It can be a sequel in name only, be loosely connected on the first title, or be a direct sequel, and a few other options.  Hyperdimension Neptunia is a little bit of one and two, in that you have to play the first to understand anything as the game sure doesn't take the time to introduce you to everyone again('If you're playing this, you've played the first' is the logic) and pretty much everything's changed, as the game takes place in another dimension, so every event that you remember in the first game goes out the window.  Some facts are still the same though, such as characters and personalities.  Since this game is trying to be a sequel, it's only fair that we look at it as a sequel, with comparisons to the first game.  The 'feel' of the game is the same, so graphics, sounds, those are pretty much the exact same, this will be more focused on the differences in gameplay and story.


So the story feels a little shorter in this one, but there's more to it as well.  Characters are introduced earlier and have much more time to get their personality fleshed out..  Although one-dimensional characters are always one-dimensional.  The well-written nature has only been improved.  In fact, there are optional characters that you can scoop up along the story that have no story presence, but plenty of optional scenes that showcase their own personality.  It's a good solution from the previous game in where you suddenly got 6 characters who have a total of 9 lines.  This way you have all your characters show their personality and quirks.  However, characters unlocked through special means that also aren't related to the story still get shunned.  It was a bit of a shocker when my party almost doubled in size in the span of a few hours of gameplay.

reviewText:
Gameplay:As a game successor you have to handle a pretty hard task. People are expecting you to be better than the first game and if the first game was outstandingly good it is even more hard to make a great successor. In this case, Rebirth 1 was challenging, funny, cute and had a great story line. And is Rebirth 2 also that great? Well, yes and no. Even though it does everything exactly as good as Rebirth 1. That is maybe also the problem. It is recycling the most animation, character design, etc and this is the problem. Yeah it might be also a great game, BUT if you are facing the same mosnters as in the first game, what is remaining? Only the story plot which is at least good enough to justify a successor. But there is still this dull aftertaste of recycling everything.

Conclusion:]But well, if you do not mind the recycling that much and you would like to see more of the same then you will get an awesome game here. It is still a great game, jus the graphics recycling makes it feel weird ( at least for me ). Never the less, I had tons of fun with this game!

Rating: 8/10
voteText: 17 of 18 people (94%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have this game on the Vita, so pay no attention to my lack of playtime. I felt compelled to write this as a word of warning before people buy the game:
1. This takes place in an alternate dimension, so don't be confused with the lack of continuity between this and Re;Birth
2. The main character is Nepgear, Neptune's younger sister, who is much more serious than Neptune. This doesn't mean the game isn't funny; it is, just not as random as Neptune makes it.
3. The storyline is more serious, but still has lots of gaming references and is still enjoyable. There's a balance between humor and drama.
4. This is the main timeline in the series, so Re;Birth 3 takes place as an immediate sequel to this game. Even if you don't like this game's seriousness, Re;birth 3 is much more funny with less drama and it helps playing this game to understand character relationships in the sequel.
5. Stella's dungeon is annoying without the DLC, so hopefully you either don't mind spending an extra $1 for that or that you don't mind skipping it.

I'm going to split this review here between people who haven't played Mk II and those who have:

For those who haven't played Mk II:
The game is a solid upgrade from Re;Birth 1 (at least, the Vita version was). You get to enjoy a familiar cast of characters along with new ones. It is set in a different universe, so there may be  a few raised eyebrows concerning character relationships. The storyline is more deep and the true end doesn't come entirely out of left field like in Re;Birth 1. That being said, be aware that Neptune, Noire, Blanc, and Vert don't show up until halfway through the game, as this game is about their little sisters (save Vert, who doesn't have one, that poor woman). I love this game. I felt that Neptune is a bit too silly as a main character and that Nepgear does really well as a leader in bringing people together. She also sees a bunch of character development, unlike Neptune who didn't really change much the entire game. This opinion might be biased by my playing Mk II which had a much slower pace, so the character development might not be as gradual in this version (even though I've played it, I already knew how it occurred so I wasn't really paying attention to it this time around). If you liked the first game, you will most likely like this game. The biggest issue is whether or not you'll appreciate Nepgear. That being said, even if you dislike Nepgear, I recommend playing it so you'll know the characters for when Re;birth 3 comes out (which has Neptune as the main character).

For those who have played Mk II:
For starters, the pace of Re;Birth 2 is much faster than the original, which can be good or bad. The story of the game kind of makes it feel like you have to gather support to and then save the world which feels like it should take a long time, which, with the way shares worked in the original, I felt like I was actually making a difference. In this version, it's so easy to manipulate shares that I feel like it breaks the flow of the game.
Something I view as flawed is that they replaced the 3D animated models from Mk II with the new sprites (the same sprites from Re;Birth 1). While I like the sprites, they aren't as animated as the 3D models, which gave the game more life.
That being said, the Remake system is definitely a massive upgrade from Mk II. The music is improved as well. Mechanically speaking, the game is much better. As I said above though, I wish for a slower pace and for the 3D models to come back.
Oh right, one more complaint: They removed Nisa and Gust and replaced them with RED and Broccoli. This is deeply upsetting to me because Nisa was amazing. I liked Gust, too, but about as much as Broccoli, so they even each other out. RED on the other hand... well, I like her appearance but I want to shove a fist down her throat whenever she opens her mouth (Probably due to her English voice).

My Opinion:
Overall, it's most likely my favorite game in the series. It's tied with the game it's based on (Hyperdimension Neptunia Mk II) because each have elements that the other would benefit from.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying rebirth 1 was an amazing game and I do recommend you buy that game first before playing rebirth 2. Make sure you read whole review so you understand what I mean.

Now due to the fact that I really didnt have high hopes for rebirth 2 cause mk2 on PS3 wasn't the greatest because of PS1 graphics and FPS issues but I didnt care because I thought this time would be different and all those issues would of been fixed. Well The graphics were just like rebirth 1 so no problem there but FPS issues oh boy let me tell you this was a slap in the face. Rebirth 1 had no issues what so ever with FPS like none always 60 fps. Now rebirth 2 had some really bad FPS issues. Most of the time the game was at 30fps even though my screen wasn't at 1920/1080p. Now you think after MK2 they would of learned from their mistakes? Guess not.

But enough of the hardware fails and on to the story and characters. Well right off the bat when I bought this game they gave me a DLC for a very overpowered weapon that killed almost everything in 1 hit. Now because of this I barely leveled any of my characters because nepgear killed everything almost instantly this kind of took the fun out of the game just a little because the game didnt have that much of a challenge. Now the story is little different from MK2. The story wasn't too bad I beat the game once without skipping anything like text and events then after that on my second and so on playthroughs I found myself skipping everything even battles because of the same old things. Now just like MK2 you have tons and tons and.... tons of endings to get 100% achievements on this game. Let me tell you I wasn't fond of this on MK2 and wasn't fond of this on rebirth 2. Plus on top of that the lilly ranks really did ♥♥♥♥ me off because you need to level them up for the endings which rebirth 1 didnt need for the endings which made the game even less enjoyable for myself.

If you're reading this and thinking why did he recommend this game even though he's telling everyone how bad the game is? The truth is I am a very hardcore fan of the hyperdimension series and even though I might hate a lot of things about the game I always find myself going back to them and finishing them up and beating everything.


Pros

- Graphics were alright just like rebirth 1 nothing new.
- A ton of things to do in the game from leveling and getting every single item drop in the game (Which takes days) -_-
- Cute characters and funny moments. (RED is pretty annoying just saying)
- BOOBS BOOBS BOOBS BOOBS
- Keeps you busy for at least 2 weeks if you grind everyday.
- 100 million gold achievement was easy.

Cons

- DLC sword made leveling pointless (Kill everything way too fast).
- Too many ending's.
- Lilly ranks are dumb.
- Not enough challenge to the game.
- Uni needs bigger boobs
- Aside from Nepgear the other cpu candidates seem weak as hell (No point on using them)
- MarvelousAQL Has bigger boobs than vert
- Bad FPS issues

In the end this game wasn't too bad but rebirth 1 was way better and I hope rebirth 3 will be even better.

Check out my review for rebirth 1

*** A somewhat more proper review ***
~ Overall I am enjoying the game. If you are a fan of Re; Birth 1 then it is more of the same. The story focuses almost entirely on the CPU Candidates (Sisters)
date:
primarily on Nepgear.

~ Playing Re; Birth 1 is not required. This game is neither a prequel nor a sequel. It helps to know a little about the characters and the world though.

~ A lot more endings than Re; Birth 1. Some are more complicated than others.

~ It's not a direct translation from the native language. In fact
recommended: some lines are just plain ridicules (mostly Nep-neps). Some major "artistic freedom" was taken advantage of here. This has some people all bent out of shape. Overall the story is the same and flows well despite some overzealous attempts at injecting a certain form of humor that wasn't present in the native language.\n\n~ Grinding. Some people like it
hoursPlayed: some hate it. I never had to specifically "go level up" in order to get past a certain point if I failed. If you're a completionist you will be doing a good amount of missions to influence "Shares" and also gathering materials for crafting Plans.\n\nI'm not going to label any of these as pro's or con's. I'm not even going to give it an arbitrary numerical rating. I am enjoying this game as mush as I enjoyed Re; Birth 1. As soon as I finish this I will be stuck eagerly awaiting Re; Birth 3."

reviewText:
This review is mainly meant for those who played Re;Birth1 since I draw a lot of comparisons between the two games based on my immense enjoyment of Re;Birth1.

-- If you want to see my first impressions after like an hour of gameplay you can scroll down a bit. --


[Updated 06/01/2015]

So now that I have about 20 hours under my belt I figured I would update my review a little.

I am currently in late chapter 4 and have take the game quite slowly by making all the dungeon plans as I go and grinding for materials, doing quests as they unlock, reading all the chirps, etc.

I am still really enjoying the game and think it is comparable to Re;Birth1 as far as quality of entertainment goes. As I mentioned previously the system remains the same, but is much more polished and the game is balanced better. You get Gear's EXE drive through storyline so you can't just cheese bosses and hard enemies as readily as you could in Re;Birth1, but it's still a very easy game if you overlevel a bit, which you will if you activate the EXP Up plan early on and grind even slightly.

The game looks a bit better than the first installment. It's mostly little things like Gear's skirt and hair being animated when she jumps. For the most part the art style and quality remains the same.

The storyline is not a continuation from Re;Birth1, but is a totally new story. Things like Compa and IF knowing eachother their whole lives and the ending(s) of Re;Birth1 being totally disregarded. The story is pretty similar to parts of the story of the anime, but is still pretty far off. It's definitely a stand alone story. Plenty of nods towards the rest of the franchise though.

I mentioned in my inital review that the game is not as fully voiced and while that is true I've only run into a small number of scenes that aren't fully voiced and they're all optional character scenes accessed through the information menu in the cities. So, hardly a con at all.

The only con I can really say the game has is a lack of costumes and that likely doesn't matter for a lot of people. The PS3 version of the game had a number of costumes for Compa and IF and they don't have a single one aside from their defaults in Re;Birth. Meh. They have plenty of headpieces though. I am just a sucker for character customization.

Overall the game is fun as hell so far. I'm really enjoying myself.

-----
[Original Review from 05/29/2015]

So far a fantastic successor to Re;Birth1.  The system remains mostly the same with a few polished things here and there.
The party now consists of four girls instead of three which was something I always wished for in Re;Birth1. There are four CPUs so it makes sense to have four slots in your party!

The story so far is interesting and I am really loving the darker feel. It doesn't just feel like an addon to the end of Rebirth 1, it really has its own feel of a unique game with a good story so far. The art is the same, but some characters looks slightly different such as Histoire. The graphics when on the field and in battle are improved and the camera control is nice.

One small disappointment is that the game isn't voiced quite as fully as Rebirth was. There are some minor scenes so far that aren't voiced at all. Really not a big deal and most scenes are still fully voiced.

I also grabbed all the DLC and it adds the 900 levels you would expect as well as some trivial starting items like nepbulls and whatever. The best thing about the DLCs so far are three starting weapons for Gear and three headpieces. Mostly they're references to the Neptunia anime and if you've watched that I'm sure you'll enjoy them. I expect that the added coliseum fights and plans will be awesome later.

All in all with just a taste of the game so far I would say it's going to be a fantastic game like the first one.
I'll, of course, update this review after beating the game once and probably again after getting all achievements.

The setting is much darker compared to Re;birth 1 and Re;birth 3, but is still enjoyable nonetheless. Chronologically, Re;birth 2 and Re;birth 3 go together, so it's okay to buy Re;birth 2 before Re;birth 1.

Re;birth 2 features a bundle of cute, loli girls that fight on a turn-based combat system. This game is addicting and incredibly fun to play, and I recommend you pick it up as well.

reviewText:
This is game #2 in the Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth series. You do not need to play the first game to understand this one. The first one is about the main four CPUs. This one is about their sisters' adventures.

Do note, because this is an IF/Compile Heart game. They tend to re-use a lot of their assets. Other than that...

Overall, it's relatively the same like Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth1. Only difference is, you can control four characters in combat instead of three. The story this time around revolves around the CPU's sisters which are personifications of handheld devices. Combat is relatively the same as the first one in the series being a positional turn-based RPG with lots of Visual Novel dialogue sequences. Several more endings in this one a lot more than the first one, so there is some replayability.

It's a cutesy RPG with lots of female characters, silly plots, and jabs at several things in the video game industry like it's predecessor in the series. If you don't enjoy this kind of thing, this game is probably not for you.

Do note, this game uses OpenGL and may not play nicely with AMD video cards at all as can be seen in the system requirements.

Also, Durante's Hyperresolution v0.2 works with Re;birth2 if you wanted to have different resolutions as well as to downsample using it.

reviewText:
Buy it.I've played it for 15 hours, and I can say that it's definately better than the first one. Even though it has a few game breaking bugs, but hey, RB1 also had those when it first came out and they've all been fixed over time. Anyways, review time:

Pros:

Advanced but easy to understand battle system: turn-based battles with attack, defend, items, skills, escape, ultimate skills, but: you can move during your turn to position yourself on the battlefield (to, for example, hit multiple enemies with penetrating skills), and after you attack once you can do combos.
This is what makes this game good even for people like me who don't like to play turn-based RPGs because the fighting is boring. There's more strategy and interaction involved in HDN.

Humorous, semi-serious plot. Also fanservice.

Animated visual novel-like cutscenes and, though very rarely, 3D cutscenes.

Nice graphics and retro music, sometimes mixed with epic music. You know, with a chorus 'n' churchbells 'n' stuff...

Steam trading cards: If you get one, go to your Steam inventory, click on it, view the badge progress, click on the thumbnail there to view the full image. Pretty nice. For example: 1 card shows 1 character cosplaying, if you view the full image you'll see all 4 characters cosplaying. :3


Step-ups from the last game:

A bit more 3 dimensional cutscenes, in RB1 there was only 1, at the beginning. The 3D cutscenes in RB2 after the intro mainly consist of animations used ingame (which are naturally looping), but it's something. I like it. I like it alot. Wish there were more than just 3 of them, tho. :|
Better effects, smexier UI
Larger dungeons which aren't being reused as often as in RB1
A more serious plot
Longer story
You can fight with 4 characters instead of 3.
More characters, you may know some from the anime and missed them in RB1.

Cons:

On occasion the voice acting may stop in visual novel-like cutscenes, together with the mouth animation.

Before starting a battle the game might crash. It only happened to me once, at the very beginning. But, depending on how well the game runs on your computer, it might happen more frequent to you.

Some of the animations are just... bad.



Conclusion:
Like I said, buy it. Even though it has a few problems, it's an awesome game.

reviewText:
Okay, yes, the game is kinda weeaboo as ♥♥♥♥, but the game delivers on its promises.  It's a decent RPG, with cute girls and silly banter, with a decent story and art theme.  My only complaint 11 hours in is that it can be a tad grindy. Occasionally you'll reach a boss that you're unable to beat, and have to spend 30-60 minutes grinding out a few more levels and items before you can beat the boss.

Compa is best girl. 8/10

EDIT: After a scene at the end of Chapter 2, featuring a level of self-awareness I didn't think possible from a game like this, as well as hilarious humor, I've upped the score to 9/10.  They know exactly what they're doing and I'm loving every second of it.

reviewText:
Re;Birth2 is a fun game and a worthy installment of the Neptunia franchise...on Vita. On PC, it's buggier than a big bug bugging out in a dune buggy:

-General performance issues causes inconsistent framerate that can tank from 60 to 9 FPS when the game loads during a dungeon.
-CG scenes are potentially hobbled by lagging audio and skipping video. Currently, I have not been able to fix this.
-Enabling select DLC (I've found the Additional Content Packs and Histoire's Rescue Plans to be hassle-free) may cause scripting errors.
-Crashes are not frequent, but can happen at critical moments where saving is not possible. Bear in mind this is my account as someone who uses an AMD GPU. Should you use an Intel one, your experience may be different and potentially worse.
-The game may not load on start-up, prompting a trip to Task Manager to end the process. Also, it may simply cut the knot and crash every time instead. These issues have not been patched.
-The game may suddenly stop recognizing controller inputs. To fix this, open up the config menu, then switch your input of choice from controller to keyboard and back again.
-Memory leaks, ho!
-If you're unlucky, you will always crash past a certain event in the plot, usually after the prologue. I had this issue for a long time, which eventually went away for no apparent reason. NO, THE GAME HAS NOT BEEN PATCHED.
-Some artwork has not been upscaled for HD resolutions, resulting in pixelation of otherwise terrific backgrounds and artwork.
-The sound mixing is awful. Dungeon music is too quiet, world map BGM is far too loud, and effects are always leaning on the extreme ends of the scale from pen drop" to "Linkin Park concert".

And those potentially aren't the last of the issues that exist.

The game has been patched in June
date: but resulted in even more problems cropping up. As a result
recommended: the patch was undone a day later. The devs have remained quiet since then
hoursPlayed: and with the release of Re;Birth3
voteText: it is unlikely Re;Birth2 will ever be fixed.\n\nI was able to soldier on through all the issues and fully complete the game on all my avaliable free time over the course of two months. It's still got the irreverent charm the series is known for
helpfulPercent: with addicting gameplay and a short-but-sweet length that compels you to come back and get all nine endings. But as a Vita owner
votesHelpful:
I have to question if it was really worth my patience.

Re;Birth2 as a game is great. Re;Birth2 as a PC port is simply dreadful.

This review will be updated should patches come out.

P.S. I've spent around 10 of my 75 hours simply finding solutions to fix my issues. On a side note
votesTotal: Re;Birth2 has repeatedly caused my computer to overheat and automatically shut down to avoid damage to internal systems. This is likely an issue relegated to myself
votesFunny: however.\n\nOne advantage the PC version does have over the Vita version is the ability to have mods. For those that find the dialogue intolerable (I personally find it fine but wish Neptune's lines were completely altered)
commentsCount: you can mod it out with a retranslation here: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=542831125"

reviewText:
PROS:

+ Neps
+ Dank Japanese maymays
+ Good humor, fun characters
+ 4th wall breaking
+ Above average voice acting
+ Lots of cute costumes and shiz

CONS:

- DLCs grant overpowered plans and equipment
- Incredibly generic gameplay
- Poor balance, difficulty can range from 'absurdly easy' to 'impossible' at various points. The game strongly encourages grinding since levels give so much stats.
- Hardly any strategy involved, just grind levels until you start crushing every enemy
- Weak, nonsensical story

VERDICT:

If you already know you're in for (i.e. the Neps), go right ahead and get this game. If you're looking for an RPG with solid gameplay and depth, this game is definitely not for you. Like many others have said, HDN is much more enjoyable if you treat it as a visual novel rather than an RPG.

reviewText:
The addition of nep nep jr. and friends

Instead of nep nep(neptunia) you are playing as her little sister nep nep jr.(nepgear) Eventually nep nep does join you on your quest but not for a bit.

Battle system
If you played the first game then its bassically that but a litle more refined  even the lilly system is more refined but for those that don't know it's basically like tales of series meets turn based combat. Which may sound bad to a select few but it works really well.

Music
mmmm nothing really new a lot of tracks were re used from the first game so i can't say to much about this.

Presentation
Easy to navigate menus makes rpg's a lot more enjoyable then people think. When your playing an rpg you want to know where everything is and you want to be ableto get to it easily this g ame eacomplishses tha. I have played some rpg's where the menu system just sucks.


Voice acting
I generally done care about voice acting in games but i will give credit when it is good. The voice actors give colorful characters  life and do it well. You can tell each character has thier own personality.

Game difficulty
Honestly a lot easier then the first game i pretty muched breezed trough it without having to look up a guide to find out where stuff was or how to get things.

Level cap
The level cap in the game (main story) is 99 but.... Im pretty sure you have to buy the dlc to get your level cap to 999! Which is nuts but if you want more enjoyement out of the game and plenty of grinding well then the dlc is for you.

Overall a decent experaince but the final boss was kind of meh ... I took it out in a few turns at level 75ish There are multiple endings super bosses ect.

reviewText:
Other than the fact that the game runs about as well as a bicycle with both its wheels popped, the game is quite nice. Every character has their own unique personality which helps add flavor to the game. The story is quite cliché, but the  characters heps set it apart from the average JRPG. This game proved to be quite the good change of pace for my inner weeaboo.

Pros:
-Unique and colorful characters
-Deviates from the average JRPG in more than one ways
-Whoever said the cliché is bad?
-Conquest ending if youre up for a good tear jerker
-Combat system that's more elaborate than one would think
-Crisp 3D models
-Addictive
-9 different endings to the game
-Blanc is best waifu

Cons:
-Cutscenes stutter when played
-Performance issues
-You want to craft something? Go get me 8 different items from 8 different mini-bosses first.
-Addictive
-Combat system is difficult to understand for most people at first
-4 of the 9 endings ore extensions of the normal ending


If you plan on buying this, be prepared to rot your eyes out. Because you will. Oh will you ever.

reviewText:
I should have wrote this review months ago but got distracted.Overall
Yeah, it's pretty awesome. My love for the Neptunia series only grows with every installment and this is no exception.

Is is the best game ever? Of course not, that title is still held by Valkyrie Profile: Lenneth, and this shall continue forever.
But Neptunia 2 is damn fun.

This review is, I imagine, going to be talking about the first game alot as, for the most part, they are extremely similar. This is more a review of the game as a sequel than as a stand alone title.

I'm still referring to the game as Neptunia 2 because I'm no less lazy than I was when I wrote the review for Neptunia 1.

Port Quality.
Not much has changed since the port for Neptunia 1, aside from that patch that killed the game for roughly twenty minutes before Idea Factory panicked and reverted it with an apology. (Good on ya, for paying attention, guys, everyone would have gone nuts without their daily Nep Nep dose and as a programmer myself I know how easy it is to overlook what it is you're not fixing.)

I did notice what I believe to be a memory leak, but it took such a long time and so much tabbing out to come into effect I don't really consider it worth mentioning.

There is, however, a problem actually worth mentioning.
I'M STILL DEAF, GUYS. WHY DO SOUND LEVELS DEFAULT TO MAX? THIS IS BAD, STOP IT.

Sounds should default to half, at most, and settings should be remembered on boot, not on load.

(This has, fortunately, been sort-of fixed as of the Fairy Fencer F port, which does tie sound levels to save files. I assume they read my amazing review and realised what to do.)

So, onto gameplay
Again, this is very much like Neptunia 1. The story does, however, begin with 100% more Lady Heart bondage in the ever-grim lands of the Console Graveyard.

In Neptunia 1, you're running around with a three Goddess party, slapping everything in sight. This isn't bad but there's something lacking, something more. A fourth slot, to be precise. Which is, rather wonderfully, part of the battle system in Neptunia 2. Though the extra slot brings you up to only four party members, everything feels better while still retaining challenge. This is such a small change but personally I find this wonderful. Three man parties don't feel nice to use and five can be too many, four is the sweet spot for many JRPGs.

Other parts of the battle system have been improved upon. You may remember me talking about how some things, such as super moves or other spells are introduced extremely early, but the moves themselves are so late to the party that you've long since forgotten they exist. The devs did it right this time and everything is introduced properly. I did already know how everything would work but from an objective perspective, the battle system is explained in a far superior fashion in this installment.

Much of everything else is the same. Dungeons are better, they're mostly more than one stage long unlike the first game, which was probably the most dissapointing part of the first game. The dungeons look better, as well, which is nice. All the post game is still locked away in the Plan System but this time there's slightly less Googling to find that one dungeon unlock you're missing. It still happens, but less so.

Everything is generally better. Except for Ai-chan (IF) who got nerfed for some reason. Presumably because she carried your party untill you got the Goddesses in Neptunia 1 and IF themselves didn't want to look too awesome too consistently. I thought it was a shame but Red, to a lesser extent, fills IF's shoes. Then you get the Goddesses back and they all get relegated to the party menu forever more anyway (except for Cave, who is wonderful in every possible way). Conversely, Neptune herself is alot better in this one. She was a little lacklustre in Neptunia 1, ironically, and the other Goddesses were just better. Neptune is much more than worth having on your party this time around.

There's also a minigame called Stella's Dungeon, which is totally brilliant and has tonnes of character for something that just fetches you items occasionally. Definitely worth a go, especially if you want those achievements.

The Story
Sadly, the story takes a bit of a hit to make room for the generallybetterineveryway rest of the game. The idea is cool and the baddies are interesting (phwoar, CFW Magic), but too much of the story is around Nepgear's self esteem issues. Which are boring. It's all well and good that Noire (and the others, I believe) tell her to pull her socks up and get on with it, but its still boring. The ending is good, there's more to get this time around, including a bad ending, which is really rather dark, and not just because they apply a monochrome filter to everything as a result. Mildly related, The final boss is a furry, instead of Arfiore proper.

Overall
The game is loads of fun, moreso to play than it's predecessor, less so as a story than it's predecessor. I'd still pay full price for it and all the DLC anyway and will do when 3 comes out because this series is fantastic. I highly recommend it to all.

Also, it must suck to live in your older sibling's shadow. Especially when your older sister is Noire and is absolute perfection, in your own game, no less.

reviewText:
The addition of nep nep jr. and friends

Instead of nep nep(neptunia) you are playing as her little sister nep nep jr.(nepgear) Eventually nep nep does join you on your quest but not for a bit.

Battle system
If you played the first game then its bassically that but a litle more refined  even the lilly system is more refined but for those that don't know it's basically like tales of series meets turn based combat. Which may sound bad to a select few but it works really well.

Music
mmmm nothing really new a lot of tracks were re used from the first game so i can't say to much about this.

Presentation
Easy to navigate menus makes rpg's a lot more enjoyable then people think. When your playing an rpg you want to know where everything is and you want to be ableto get to it easily this g ame eacomplishses tha. I have played some rpg's where the menu system just sucks.


Voice acting
I generally done care about voice acting in games but i will give credit when it is good. The voice actors give colorful characters  life and do it well. You can tell each character has thier own personality.

Game difficulty
Honestly a lot easier then the first game i pretty muched breezed trough it without having to look up a guide to find out where stuff was or how to get things.

Level cap
The level cap in the game (main story) is 99 but.... Im pretty sure you have to buy the dlc to get your level cap to 999! Which is nuts but if you want more enjoyement out of the game and plenty of grinding well then the dlc is for you.

Overall a decent experaince but the final boss was kind of meh ... I took it out in a few turns at level 75ish There are multiple endings super bosses ect.

reviewText:
PROS:

+ Neps
+ Dank Japanese maymays
+ Good humor, fun characters
+ 4th wall breaking
+ Above average voice acting
+ Lots of cute costumes and shiz

CONS:

- DLCs grant overpowered plans and equipment
- Incredibly generic gameplay
- Poor balance, difficulty can range from 'absurdly easy' to 'impossible' at various points. The game strongly encourages grinding since levels give so much stats.
- Hardly any strategy involved, just grind levels until you start crushing every enemy
- Weak, nonsensical story

VERDICT:

If you already know you're in for (i.e. the Neps), go right ahead and get this game. If you're looking for an RPG with solid gameplay and depth, this game is definitely not for you. Like many others have said, HDN is much more enjoyable if you treat it as a visual novel rather than an RPG.

reviewText:
Like the game before it, Rebirth 2 tells the story of four CPU goddesses and their fight to save video games.

The story is set in an alternate universe from the original. The angle of the four fighting to decide best console is dropped to focus more on their war with piracy. Also unlike the first, the subtlety is dropped: the villain is the embodient of piracy, sin, and destruction, and the evil organization seeks to fill the world with bootlegs and illegal downloads. When the game begins, the CPUs are subdued and held captive. Without the four to protect their lands, their sisters, fittingly inspired by handhelds, are forced to take up the cause.

The game itself is very much a sequel. Much of it remains unchanged, if only because Rebirth 1 was inspired by its sequel, but much more focus and polish has gone into the game. The game's humor and quirkiness remains intact, and even more self-aware than before, even eager to lampshade the younger moe cast and take shots at the otaku fanbase. The world, art, locations, and enemies are reused from the older game, but a good number of new environments and monsters are added. The music just as strong. The grind is also lessened from before, particularly if you invest in the DLC and get some helpful bonuses off the bat.

The battle system still involves choosing between attacks that focus on reducing enemy guard, dealing heavy HP damage, or building a combo meter for special attacks. Characters have unique techniques that drain their SP (MP) or powerful attacks that drain a certain amount of the combo meter. A notable change is that the party limit is now four, allowing for a larger meter and more combination attacks between certain members.

The Remake sytem also returns, allowing players to craft recipes that add new items to stores or dungeons to the world map, alter dungeons, their items, and the monsters within, or even add new characters to the party.

A new function is Stella's Dungeons, which allows you to assign an NPC to expolore dungeons you've discovered. She can find new items for herself or you to use, or possibly fail and lose everything (without the proper DLC, anyway). The exploration is done in real time, which can be annoying for players who don't want to toy with their computer's clock.

However, while the game itself is sound, the port is not. FPS drops when Guard Break triggers are common (check the guides for a fix), cutscenes can lag, loading can sometimes be Iffy, and many report freezing around a certain Castle. Most of these issues are minor or only seem to affect the minority, so you'll probably be safe. Probably.

Overall, if you enjoyed the first game, you'll enjoy this one, too.

reviewText: Ahhh, console video games (or vidcons as I call them), the ultimate medium of expression, able to convey any emotion from hatred to love, loyalty to fear, all in front of your eyes. Ah, and with lovingly crafted art, music, and the ability to control the action, vidcons are the ultimate combination of the high arts. While I tend to play the stoic, I will be the first to admit that vidcons have driven me to cry, to scream and shout, to feel actual hate; such is the power of this force beyond our wildest reckoning. And here I am, before you, to tempt your tongues with the taint of such a tantalizing topic. And the Japanese, the true geniuses behind the world of video games. Pah, I throw my scorn upon such incompetents of the West who would mock the true art of the Japanese with games" such as Baldur's Gate and Madden. Perhaps the West is not as intelligent as the East

reviewText:
I'm still early in so far, but I can say if you are interested in JRPGs with cute characters and light hearted stories with VN style presentation you may enjoy this game. There is a big grind to collecting items however, so be advised of that.

-Pros-
*Combat system is fun, but not overly complicated
*Cute colorful characters and environments to brighten up your day
*Has some decent humor in it, so even if it's not LOL funny, there will be lots of smiles and grins (Nepgear is not the comedian that Neptune was, but she is easy to like because she is gentle and kind-hearted.)
*Sharper, higher resolution assets compared to Re:1 in many cases (Menu, in game rendering, and much of the art looks good on 1080p, where Re:1 had lots of art that was obviously scaled up to 1080p making it look soft and blurry)
*Old familiar environments have been revamped with different layouts to freshen up your grind
*While some familiar enemies return, there are new ones as well and the variety seems a tad better than Re:1
*Lots of reasons to replay after you clear because its just not possible to unlock most things on the first pass, and there are multiple endings to unlock

-Cons-
*Not all art was upgraded for 1080p, the 2D character graphics used during VN sequences are noticeably upscaled, clashing with the high resolution backdrops and interface
*Story isn't quite as interesting, feels more like a side story (not a deal breaker really)

-DLC Tips-
If you use Nepgears DLC weapons, particularly the strongest one, you will 1 hit bosses for several levels. Nepgear will 1 hit kill bosses for 40k damage when you are level 2 or 3, she will do about 40x the damage of other party members the same level.  So either don't equip them early on, or just chalk it off to her being Neptune's sister who of course is an over the top badass.

The DLC is optional, can be enabled or disabled at any time. So if you hear complaints about OP items or the controversial LVLUP plan, remember you can reserve those for when you think they fit your style. With 999 levels available(assuming you have the DLC), having something to speed that up isn't a bad thing at all.

You will be playing this for multiple playthroughs if you want to really unlock stuff. There are hundreds if not thousands of plans to unlock to access more characters, dungeons, enemies, battles and items. So I would keep this in mind.


-Performance- Tested on with Intel HD Graphics 4600 and Nvidia GTX 760 @ 1080p
*Runs @ 60fps mostly with GTX760 There are some frame drops into the 40s and a brief fps drop once you execute a guard break. Nothing game breaking and honestly easy to ignore.(Re;1 dropped to 30fps at the start of battles, and would then climb back up. This strange quirk is gone)
*Runs well enough on Intel HD Graphics 4600* So if you have a dedicated card you should have no issues

*25-30fps battles, 15fps victory poses (lots of camera movement), 40-50 fps for EXE Moves

reviewText:
Lots of similarities to the first game but generally worse in almost every way. Skip this game and go straight to 3, you will miss no important plot and have a much more entertaining experience.

If you do choose to purchase and play this game I would highly recommend:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=544878587

Without it, the game is unbearably laggy in combat no matter your rig (issues with 'guard break')

Other issues:
- Many repeated areas from the first game
- 4 main characters are whiny, immature and unlikable, nothing like the original 4 goddesses
- Zero continuity with plot of first or third game
- Inconsistent difficulty: Battling the other CPUs in the early game is too hard, fighting the final boss is WAY too easy
- 'Underling' boss in encountered over and over again, making her a huge part of the plot, but there is never any final resolution or battle to settle things without doing a specific special ending (theres like 8 endings to the game).
- So much emphasis is placed on 'end game' content that just involves you playing the game 3+ times to unlock all the characters and get the 'proper' ending. Or give up and give it a nasty review, one of the two.

This last one is the biggest issue. The game feels terribly underdeveloped compared to the first and third. The devs must have realized they were short on content so they made the bonus unlockable characters & True ending" require multiple playthroughs to accomplish.

I have heard people claim you can get all achieves with 3 playthroughs. Mere mortals will likely take 4 or 5. Without a guide giving you the exact conditions you could play this game 20 times and still not 100% it."

reviewText:
If you think you'll like it, you probably will. If you think you'll hate it, you probably will. That's the most you can say about this genre. It does push the fanservice pretty hard in some of the required cutscenes and most of the optional ones, and the characters are great and they interact well with each other, but they can also be a bit one sided at times. If you loved the first one, you'll love this one. They could probably even be the same game.

Pros:
-Fun dialogue
-Fun character's/ interaction
-Multiple endings

Cons:
-To some, the exterior (moe)
-Combat can be boring, especially in NG+
-Grind heavy in the beginning, but gets easier
-Good luck getting all the endings on your own
-Conquest ending :(

I recommend it.

Obligatory Neptune is best waifu" here."

reviewText:
In some ways, the game play for Neptuna Re;Birth 2 is far better than the first. Having a four member party, for instance? Way better than 3.

However, the endings are a lot less fun to chase after. Having to futz with all of those lily levels so much can get really frustrating, and unlike in 1, maps do not stay unlocked when you replay. So if you NG+ and forget to get some item for a plan you didn't have yet, you have to wait until the plot loops.

Nepgear is also not really as good at being a protag as Neptune was. She isn't unlikable or anything, but she lacks a strong personality. She's just wishywashy about everything. This makes her the straight man" (none of those meanings are accurate besides the less funny one who is somewhat serious) which she is okay at

reviewText:
In short, I would totally recommend this game.

I've played the first Re;birth game on the Vita and if you're wondering if you need to play the games in order, don't fear. Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 2 takes place in a different dimension.

So what's new in this game? Its's not too much of a change from Re;birth 1. Same battle system as the first game which was inspired by the battle system in HDN Victory. There is a 4 person team (with 4 more as backup) instead of 3 (with 3 as backup). There's a new little feature where you send a character to go get items for you while you quest. That's pretty much it.

If you haven't played a Hyperdimansion Neptunia game, it's pretty simple. A fun JRPG with lots of cute characters, fan service and a nice battle system. When I say lots of cute characters, I seriously mean it. You will be flooded with characters to choose from in your battle roster. If you like cute girls, anime, Japanese games, girls in suggestive positions, panties or 4th wall breaking, this game is for you.

reviewText:
If you invested more than 100 hours into the first Re;Birth and want to continue playing something exactly similar, get this one. Otherwise play something else.

Re;Birth2 reuses very much things from the Re;Birth 1. New Characters are few and the old ones have remained the same. They look, sound and even their moveset has remained exactly same. Of course characters are unlocked in a different order, so fighting in the early part of the game feels a bit different. However, most of the areas are new. Most new stuff is in music and voice acting (duh). New  music tracks are nice, but they are inaudible or will drown under every other sound because of  botched up sound levels. Unlike Re;Birth1, this one isn't fully voice acted and perhaps 10% of scenes are missing sound. Because of high reuse, Re;Birth2 doesn't really feel like a new game after Re;Birth1.

Re;Birth2 has its stand-alone issues and annoyances. Some game-design choises are really hard to understand. The biggest problem of the game is bad scripting and it is worsened by a very awful english translation. When the first game was absolutely nonsense and therefore great, this one is clichéd growthstory of timid a girl into the role of world savior. Also making piracy focus of the story doesn't really work. This is especially because without humour the topic turns easily into preaching. Good side of the script are new side characters. However making only fun of character's one-dimensional personality doesn't work on the fifth or sixth encounter.

Interesting feature of the game is that it has 4 unique endings. Two of those endings change storyline of the last chapter and one adds extra chapters. This means there is maybe 20 hours of (alternative/additional/hidden) game content.

However there are some huge issues considering the endgame and those chapters. First of them is that there isn't even a single hint in the game about how to obtain those endings. Because of that the player is forced to seek answers from the internet which is always negative thing for a game.

Second problem is forced NG+. In order to be able to view next ending, the game has to be completed again. Only inventory, character lvls and plans are carried over. This  means that all of the characters have to be recruited again and effectively most of the late game characters become useless. Also several hours of gameplay is required to reach areas already visited. In worst case you might want some material for a plan from some late area but are playing NG+.

In Re;Birth2 case NG+ doesn't add anything to the new to the game, it is only forced running through of underleveled enemies and it gets tedious. Second time might be manageable, but fourth forced playthrough is really a task... I watched quite much tv while playing Re;Birth2

In addition one really weird thing in Re;Birth2 is clothing. In Re;Birth1 vanity items were a huge feature; literally several hundreds pieces of clothing to make your girls prettier/original looking. In Re;Birth2 those same pieces of clothing cost 50 times more. With the price of a single hairpin you could often decent new weapons, armors and accessories for the whole party. And outfits... they cost more than final weapons of the main game.

About the DLC: The stuff in those is very very late game related (everything else is done related). Consider buing those only after you have played 100 hours or more and still want to start grinding exp.

reviewText:
I've never finished a second entry into a series with such high praise. It's almost immediately gratifying when you launch the game, go into the first dungeon, and see the world has actual elevation. (Let's not count the straight up/down jumps in RB1; Aside from those, the world was almost entirely flat.)

The only bad I have to note about the game is a bit messy on a technical level. Breaking Guards will cause FPS drops, severe or slightly noticable depending on your PC(There is a workaround, but then, said workaround can cause crashes or japanese text. In which case, play without the workaround for areas where it crashes)

Other than that, this game is a far more polished game than rebirth 1 was.(I liked Rebirth 1, for the record. 2 just felt better

reviewText:
A decent improvement from Mk2 in all ways, appreciated the new ending and the Rebirth system allowed for much more to do.

Found some of the plans a little grindy when collecting for the 200 achievement and the 100 Million Credits coming back made for a couple hours of tedium, but then again grinding is nothing new in a JRPG. I truly did not enjoy the addition of Stella's Dungeon though, without being able to manipulate your laptop's clock I imagine it would truly ruin the 100% experience.

Those nitpicks aside, Re;Birth2 is a worth successor to the original and I thoroughly recommend it, particularly if you have enough gaming knowledge to appreciate the humour.

reviewText:
[ENG] And here we are with this second awesome Nep Season :D I absolutely enjoyed both Re;Birth1 & 2, and i appreciated most the first one for some things and the second one for other things. First of all i don't agree with automatically activating the DLC Pippin Set (thank you for still reminding Fairy Fencer <3), Eye Maks and that ridiculously OP sword from the beginning. In fact i refused to play with such advantage and i acted as if nothing was there. Also i admit that despite this detail, this chapter wasn't as challenging as the first one, it was very easy and the bosses weren't tough. However the storyline is way more complicated in this title, there are many different endings and they are very long to achieve. While talking about the gameplay and the graphics (and again... some bosses), they are still the same of Re;Birth1. However i don't blame this aspect, because i really cared about the plot, strengthened with the new cute CPU Candidates.
So... nothing else to say, if you enjoyed Re;Birth1 then i suggest you to follow this awesome series (maybe waiting like me for a pretty Steam Sale :D).

Ps: Despite i fell in love with Nepgear, liked a lot Chika, Falcom and 5pb, i have to admit that Neptune is Neptune, NEPNEP IS WAY TOO KAWAII ^^ (Noire and HDD Neptune are currently my best Hyperdimenion Waifus).
Oh i was almost forgetting... WHERE DID MAGES GO??? DID SHE FOUND HER DR. PEPPER? WHO KNOWS... EL.....PSY......KONGROO......

[ITA] Ed eccoci con questo secondo fantastico episodio :D Mi sono davvero divertito a giocare sia il primo che il secondo capitolo, uno mi è piaciuto più dell'altro per diversi motivi e viceversa per l'altro.
Prima di tutto non concordo con il fatto che sin dall'inizio del gioco si ha la possibilità di avere il DLC del set di Pippin (grazie per aver ricordato ancora Fairy Fencer <3), gli accessori e quella spada ridicolmente OP. Infatti mi sono rifiutato di  giocarmi questo titolo con questi vantaggi e mi sono goduto il tutto facendo finta di niente. Ma nonostante questo dettaglio, devo dire che a differenza del primo capitolo qui per tutto il gioco non c'è stata una grande sfida, è stato tutto fin troppo scorrevole senza intoppi. Comunque la trama risulta molto più complessa e infatti ci sono molti più finali da conseguire, e il tutto richiede davvero parecchio tempo. Parlando di gameplay e di grafica, è rimasto tutto invariato (e di nuovo... anche certi boss). Ma non critico questo aspetto, anzi, il punto chiave di questo gioco è la trama, aspetto che viene rafforzato in questo capitolo ulteriormente con la comparsa delle nuove kawaii candidate CPU :D Quindi... non c'è molto da aggiungere, se il primo capitolo vi è piaciuto allora vi consiglio altrettanto Re;Birth2. (Magari ad un prezzo un pò più ragionevole, aspettate come me per i saldi!)

Ps: Nonostante mi sia innamorato  di Nepgear (soprattutto!), Chika, Falcom e 5pb, non c'è niente da fare ma Neptune è Neptune, NEPNEP E' TROPPO KAWAII ^^ (Noire e Neptune in forma HDD sono attualmente le mie Waifu preferite di Hyperdimension Neptunia).
Quasi dimenticavo... CHE FINE HA FATTO MAGES??? AVRA' TROVATO LA SUA DR. PEPPER? CHI LO SA... EL......PSY......KONGROO.....

reviewText:
I've been following HDN series since the first game release for the PS3 and this remake for HDN: mk2 is a masterpiece like its predecessor Re;birth 1. The story received a fresh tweak, added more contents and the adorable Stella whilst leaving the humor intact. The game play is still very much the same so players who played the first game will have little to no effort adapting to the slight changes.
As for new players, it isn't necessary to play the first game before playing this one as the story line is completely different and has no connection to its predecessor.
A fun and cute JRPG with loads of grinding, achievement hunting, Yuri undertones and the infamous jump spamming in glorious HD.

I'd totally recommend this to people who likes cute girls doing cute things. Also, Nepgear's voice is addicting.
A 10/10. See you all in Gamindustri~

reviewText:
In short, I would totally recommend this game.

I've played the first Re;birth game on the Vita and if you're wondering if you need to play the games in order, don't fear. Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 2 takes place in a different dimension.

So what's new in this game? Its's not too much of a change from Re;birth 1. Same battle system as the first game which was inspired by the battle system in HDN Victory. There is a 4 person team (with 4 more as backup) instead of 3 (with 3 as backup). There's a new little feature where you send a character to go get items for you while you quest. That's pretty much it.

If you haven't played a Hyperdimansion Neptunia game, it's pretty simple. A fun JRPG with lots of cute characters, fan service and a nice battle system. When I say lots of cute characters, I seriously mean it. You will be flooded with characters to choose from in your battle roster. If you like cute girls, anime, Japanese games, girls in suggestive positions, panties or 4th wall breaking, this game is for you.

reviewText:
If you're interested in Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth2, chances are that you already played the first game from the Re;Birth series, liked it to some degree and are looking for more. Gameplay wise, Re;Birth2 offers just that. It's practically the same game as its predecessor at the core, with a few minor chances.

Compared to the first game, Re;Birth2 has a better presentation, it looks more refined and polished. The gameplay is exactly the same with just one change - you can now bring one additional party member to the field, for a total of four.

Unfortunately, the content seems to have taken a turn for the worse. The characters and the story look less involved and more superficial than before. The goddess candidates aren't quite as fleshed out as their elder counterparts were.
The main antagonist for the first half of the game, while never particularly menacing to beging with, keeps recurring time and again to the point where nobody could take her seriously anymore. Granted, the previous game didn't really have a threatening villain either, but seeing the same character try for another round after a dozen failed attempts to sabotage us, one can't help but wonder what's going on in their heads. Similar levels of incompetence are displayed by the heroines, who manage to let their enemies get away with it each and every time, despite outclassing them on several levels.

The leveldesign (more specifically, the copy-pasted dungeons), one of the biggest drawbacks of the predecessor, has been improved quite a bit, but ultimately it still leaves to be desired.
On the other hand, Re;Birth2 is much more linear. While about half of the dungeons in the previous game were optional side content, this one barely offers more a handful, which forces you onto an almost completely linear path. However, Re;Birth2 does have multiple different endings, and some dungeons are restricted to chapters only accessible by certain endings. Which, unfortunately, brings me to another point: materials from these dungeons are required for certain Stronger Enemies" Plans
