reviewText:
After how epic the first game was i had come to expect a lot from this one, the sequel. The difference in this one is that you are using the younger sisters of the charecters from the first game. Those sisters got put into a trap and you(as Nepgear) have embarked on a quest to get them back. In the mean time game industry is being plagued with piracy and cheats breaking the economy.

So what to say about this then, well firstly the storyline is shorter then the first game, with 1 playthrough i took 23 hours to finish the original campaign, this took 18 hours. That being said the first game had two endings, i believe this has six or seven each with their own requirements. Beyond that the whole of the roster from the first game make a stand(apart from peachy and plutia as far as i know) but you have to earn them instead of them just being thrown at you as part of the campaign, there are a few graphical changes to the recurring charecters as well and a few more combo ex skills for our protagonists.

Generally the formula hasnt changed much, some will like that while others will not, pretty much all of the features from the first game return in addition there is a new charecter by the name of stella which you can throw into dungeons and she will give you all the crap she finds, she works in real time even if you arent playing the game so for example if you send her off for 12 hours and then sleep for a day when you launch the game she will be done searching whatever she is doing, a neat feature but not amazing. There appears to be more plan content however as for clothing it could just be me but it seems like there is less of that.

The general banter and stupidity between the charecters is still there also which is great as it is just as hilarious as the first game, its still dubbed and subbed so you get to pick what you like more. A small issue is that there are a few areas which didnt get dubbed, this isnt the end of the world and it doesnt effect the storyline or quality

A minor issue that i would like to point out is that there is a cache issue with the game and it turns into a problem, basically the game will crash when you try to enter a dungeon, seems quite game breaking, well whatever it is there is a simple solution, change the shortcut that steam uses to the exe in the game directory, no clue what its about and you would think that this is the link that is already being used.

The game runs at 60fps 99% of the time(you can push it higher in an ini file easily) anyways when you break the enemy defence the game will drop to 30fps for about half a second, sometimes you will notice it sometimes you will not, i have no clue why that happens, it something that i would like fixed however it really isnt gamebreaking.

In the end i still think that the first game was better, i believe that is because i like the personalities of that game a little better however this is a worthy sequel to that game without a doubt, there are many hours of fun in this game, if you like anime, rpgs, jrpgs, hack n slash or comedy in general the hyperdimension series is one hell of a buy.

While it works fine with keyboard it works better with a controller.

reviewText:
Ah, the sequel. I ended up getting this also on sale. I actually would pay more for this game than the first. Not sure about the $30, but I'm less reluctant about paying that much. I would say a definite yes at $15

I like this game better than the first. I think it's the protagonist, and the sisters. It's not because Nepgear's Japanese voice is Yui Horie, a famous singer and anime character voice in Japan.

Nepgear is probably the most boring character in the series, but as a protagonist, it works. Chrono of Chrono Trigger really isn't that interesting, but that doesn't matter as much because the player is the one that makes him interesting. The same I feel goes with Nepgear. You actually feel like you are Nepgear. This is unlike the first game, where I felt like I was just along for the ride with Neptune. Nepgear is the girl next door-type character, but she also is a pretty blank slate. Because of this, I feel that she is allowed to grow as a person in this game

The conquest ending would almost only be possible with Nepgear, and I bet the creator of the game felt like it would be a good opportunity to write it. I would recommend doing that ending because it's actually an incredibly well-written arc. You can see the many reactions it has already gotten in these reviews

It feels like the main CPUs/goddesses are made by a how to design a Japanese cartoon character personality" book

reviewText:
EDIT: Finishing the game with Conquest Ending, completely changes my view on the game...

Being an RPG, this game is pretty average based on other more mainstream RPGs we have today. The game shines more so however in the characters.

If your a pretty big anime fan, or fluent gamer, this game is filled with references to popular animes, and video game-related products. The entire concept of the Hyperdimension series is four goddesses; representing an old cancelled Sega console (The Sega Neptune), Xbox, Playstation and the Nintendo Wii, which ironically enough are engaged in a war coincidentally called The Console War"(sound familiar?). And this game in particular focuses on the goddess's younger sisters. Which represent the "portable" versions of what the CPUs represent
hoursPlayed: and the Sega Game Gear. Aside from the obvious references

votesHelpful: playstation or any other video game platform aside from steam.\n\nAll in all
votesTotal: in order to enjoy the game to it's fullest
votesFunny: you need to be able to recognize a bunch of the references it has. And since the game was developed as a monument to console gamers and anime fans alike

reviewText:
To make this shorter: If you enjoyed Re;Birth 1, pick up this as it's largely similar. If you haven't played Re;Birth 1, check that out first as this game's story will make a lot more sense if you do.

Differences between this and Re;Birth1 are:
- 8-player parties instead of 6-player (you use 4 active characters and have another 4 at the 'back' who act as assists and can be switched in if needed)
- More of a focus on the CPU Candidate characters (Nepgear, Uni, Rom and Ram). You only really get back to the original CPU cast later, depending on your actions
- Way more endings, you'll need to complete this a lot of times if you want to see every ending.

Personally I prefer Re;Birth 1 because of the story. The second game is decent but some things feel very forced (such as fighting Underling/Warechu almost all the time). The game actually pokes fun at this but it doesn't make it any less dull. I don't really think the story for Re;Birth 2 is as strong as the original but that shouldn't stop you playing it. The battle system is still fun and there's still a wide variety of characters to experiment with.

Would recommend but only if you've played the first Re;Birth game beforehand.

reviewText:
Sooooo, the Mk.2 has been remastered in english and god it's enjoyable, i personally haven't played the original but from what i've seen the games are almost the exact same besides the higher texture quality and the replacment of 2D character sprites instead of 3D Models during text conversations, which looks better in my opinion as it fits the drawn background and the CG models don't take you out of the atmosphere.

The gameplay is more of the same old hyperdimension that we all know (somewhat) and love! The story is somewhat interesting and the combat is fully fleshed out, compitent, and thought invoking. The animations are high quality and the Sp skills and E.X.E drives are beautiful and look breath taking. The game also spices it up with a consistant amount of humour that some may find annoying, I usually ignore the humour but sometimes i do get quite a kick out of them, such as Uni's Charley Horse ability (Plus it's damn hot <3)

Overall this game is fun, time consuming, and most importantly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ FUN! For anyone who has previously played a Hyperdimension Game this is an instant buy

My final score for Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 2 is a : 9/10 This game is amazing engaging and never lets the pace down, and if you have the money lying around this is definetely worth a buy! I can't wait to see more ports from the PsVita to steam of the Hyperdimension Franchise!

reviewText:
For the following review, I will be referring to Re;Birth1 and Re;Birth2 as RB1 and RB2.

In terms of story, I feel RB2's is much better than RB1's. RB1 I would consider a happy go lucky adventure, although it did have its moments. RB2 on the other hand, it felt darker. Don't get me wrong, there were a fair share of silly moments, but the game did have more dark and emotional moments than RB1. I felt more engaged in this story. I wanted to see what happens next. It had me hooked, and I love games that do that.

The protagonist this time around is Nepgear, Neptune's younger sister. While some don't like her, I actually find her to be a good lead character. She's a shy girl with confidence issues who has a heavy burden placed on her shoulders. Actually, all the candidates have some kind of issue that plagues them. In my opinion, this makes them all the more relatable and likeable. You want to see these girls overcome their fears.

For gameplay, it's pretty much the same as RB1's but with some changes. The first and most noticeable change is that you can have a party of four now. That right there is a simple change, but a much welcomed change. Having a four person party really opens up the floodgates for potential strategies. Another thing I like is that human characters feel more useful now. In RB1, I would mainly just stick with CPUs because I felt the human characters were a bit too weak for my liking. In RB2, I find more human characters on my team now. They feel stronger than they were previously, and some are just outright awesome (Cave). Finally, this is a bit difficult to explain, but I find this game to be more balanced. I don't feel that it throws any curve balls at the player in terms of difficulty. The difficulty itself seems to progress with the player.

Next up is the soundtrack, which to me is really good. From the relaxing tunes of the resort and forest levels to the upbeat tunes of the CFW and normal battle music. It's all great and worth listening to.

Graphics are as colorful and organic as ever.

This game is worth every penny.

reviewText:
I made a pixel girl jump and she said yipee, I saw her panties and I said yipee it's win win.

Game play it's just like Hyperdimension Neputian Rebirth 1 and has the same controls and battle system ect only this time it's focus is on the CPU's little sisters. There's bags of colour, fun and humor that takes the ♥♥♥♥ out of gaming and anime on the whole.

It's so wrong to play with little girls but oh so right this game serise is my number one guilty pleasure od 2015.

I rate this 8/10 as it's a clone with a reskin but then it doesn't pretend it's not either ;)

reviewText:
To IFI
Please fix the game banner, seriously... Fixed... thanks.

Review
- Extremely cute characters. >w<
- AFAIK, the story is pretty more intense/dramatic than Re;Birth1.
From my understanding, the story seems to be a parody of piracy issues.
(and you should feel bad when you pirated this game lol)
- There's a lot more things to do in this game compared to Re;Birth1.
- No problems occurred with the port so far. Got a crash sometime...
(FYI, I don't get any problem when playing Re;Birth1)

reviewText:
Why you must buy this?
1. If you love kawaii girl, we have Nepgear here.
2. If you love tsundere girl, we have Uni here.
3. If you love lolis, of coruse we have Rom and Ram here.
So why not you buy this? Just click 'add to cart' already dude

Pros :
- All aspects in Neptunia Re;Birth1
- 1 More slot party, make your team more overwhelm the enemy (LoL)
- New Minigame, even i don't know which use of this minigame except for Medal (maybe will give you great plan later?)
- Nepgear there
- I said nepgear there? yeah nepgear there
- Once again nepgear there

Cons :
- I just wonder, why steam give free DLC for Nepgear weapon, it will ruin starting game if you use that.
I mean without that, this game pretty much easy rather than RB1 (Maybe you should activate Fortify Enemy)
- The joke sometimes seems off (i love how neptune and noire back then at RB1, or with blanc and vert). Thanks to puchiko for her nyu.
- I just annoying how the story can be different or not connected with Re;Birth1, for example when first time Neptune meet Compa and IF for first time. Noooo why you do this IF !!

So for me this game rate is 9/10
Because Nepgear is the MC !! Yaayy !!

reviewText:
If you liked the first one you'll probably like this one as well
*this takes place in an alternate world from that of the first game
*there are also 9 endings
*apparently the dlc breaks the game and makes you lvl up too fast if thats a problem then disable them
*game also has similar crashing problems to that of the first

How to fix game crash (same as first game)
•Run as admin
•Run as Windows xp sp 3
•Install visual c++ 2013 x86 version even if you are using 64 bit windows

Overall I'm really enjoying this game so far can't wait for the third one to be ported in the fall

reviewText: Very similar to how the first one runs; available at 1080p and 60fps and features the same mechanics of combat that was present in the first one. reviewText:
The Game has the same basic gameplay as the 1st game and its not really a continuation of the 1st games story its a new dimension and it has a great cast of characters and new ones to see what so far is showing the comedy side of the franchise but it does have it serious moments.
The dlc is worth it for some good weapons to start off with if you are a first time player and if you like to grind levels then its worth it for a lvl boost of up to 999 and there might be more in the future i dont know but for now its worth the buy.
The gameplay like i said is simple with the same stuff like HDD, EXE drive, Sp attacks and regular attacks so there is no need to worry about a new system or battle unless you are a first time player then i recommend reading the information given to you at certian points on how to play the game.
Overall the game is worth the pick up for fans of the franchise or people who like jrpgs.

reviewText:
I loved Re;birth1.
And I want to like this game.

Main concern:
But there's so much content copied from Re;Birth 1 that it doesn't feel new or unique at all.
Characters, character sprites, attacks, BGM, items, plans, complete dungeons, even some dialogues.
It often feels like a DLC which forces you to regrind everything you already had.

To make things worse sometimes the events and story actually contradicts the one from Re:Birth1!
(E.g. An event in chap3 gets the first meeting of Compa, IF, Nepear and Neptune COMPLETELY wrong!)

The story:
IN MY EYES Nepgear doesn't fit a protagonist, she is so whiney that dialogues often get a drag to read, opposed to the fun conversations of the first part. Overall the story itself feels worse and and overall lacks effort, the Team-Rocket-esque antagonists don't help....


Conclusion:
Overall good gameplay - like Rebirth 1 had.
However, if you played Re;birth 1 you might as well replay it.
Players who are new to the franchise should definitely purchase Re;birth 1 instead.
voteText: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Hyper Dimension Neptunia Re;Birth 2 is the PC-port of the remastered Hyper Dimension Neptunia Mk2 originally released on the PS3 platform in 2012. This remastered version, which was optimised for the PS Vita portable platform, is definitely an inferior version to the original game, with less movies than in the PS3 version and the lack of the Keiji Inafune's cameos (and subsequently the lack of the infamous Inafune sword and beam attacks for NepGear). https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bXAl8skbocQ

The replacement of NISA and Gust with RED and Broccoli, while seamless, also removed a couple of coupled EX skills that are apparently not replaced. Personally, I'm still quite sad to get no prinny and atelier references without the two companies.

Negativity aside, Neptunia Re;Birth 2 is still a pretty good game game filled with comedic moments. The story remain true to the original game, which still make it the best of the series IMO. Definitely a must-play if you'd always wanted to experience the craziness in a light-hearted JRPG.

reviewText:
Solid port and lots of improvements from the first game. The map doesn't get nearly as obstructed when you start unlocking lots of new items and enemies. Some rudimentary materials such as Herb drop more often so you can actually finish your item plans before you stop needing them. Stella's Dungeon is a nice minigame and you can get useful items/materials that way too. You can put four girls on the field instead of three so you can actually have all four goddesses/candidates out at the same time.

The most common problem people are having is the game choking up whenever there's a Guard Break (multiple times per battle), which destroys your framerate for 1-5 seconds. I'm expecting this to be fixed soon.

English voices are hilariously bad, Japanese voices are hilariously good. The translation has some glaring localization issues.

RB2 is quite easy (perhaps a bit harder than RB1) so I recommend you dont use all those broken items and plans you get right at the start. The game has been very enjoyable so far.

reviewText:
After accidentlly completing the first game had to go and get the 2nd installment.  More or less the same game. Could have actually been an add-on/DLC for Re;Birth 2 but still a nice game.

Pros:
Comical characters, puns, items/weapons/outfits/CPU's
Felistella - a real time RPG that runs in the background as you play. An JRPG within a JRPG
Tsunako - awesome artist with vibrant characters.


Cons:
Nepgears group not as fun as Neptunes group.
Mostly a copy & paste game with enemies and enviroments
Too many characters too manage
Too easy after grinding out.

reviewText:
The Pros :
The sequel is improved a little from the first game.
1. +1 member party in battle instead of 3.
2. A lot of party members
3. Multiple endings. A LOT.
4. The battle system is similar like the previous game, so yeah, its fun.
5. Musics.
6. Anime girls. Duh.

The Cons :
1. Boring and repetitive quests, like always.
2. Boring and lack of designs of the monsters, like always.
3. Lack of character's development, not the main char, but the side characters. Like always.
4. Lack of dungeon's design. Like always.
5. I'm kinda confused with the story, especially the prologue. It seems like..
It doesn't really connected at all with the previous game. Like IF tells Nepgear how she met Neptune for the first time and she said that she fell from the sky but in the first game they met in the dungeon, not from the sky.
And I was like..WTF ?

7,5/10 - Otherwise, this game is still good.
So, how many New Game+ do you need to get all the endings ? A lot.
Well, you can just make a bunch of save files though and I ain't got time for that.
I'm done.
Ah, don't forget that you need Lily Rank for certain endings !
GLHF.

reviewText:
I'm quite a fan of the franchise but Neptunia Rebirth 2 is something that I cannot recommend as much I wanted to love this game. Some technical problems, unecessary gameplay additions, and boring story is what makes this game falls short compared to its predecessor.

It's the same game as the previous installment with only minor additions. But that very minor additions is what makes the game worse than it predecessor, at least if you're aiming to get all achievements. Take, for example, stella's dungeon. It's suppossed to be some kind of 'passive income' since stella does net you some plan materials but it's just not worth it in my opinion as it adds almost nothing to the gameplay. Hell, it can be ignored altogether and i think no one will miss a thing. And on top of that the achievement for it feels like a test of patience, and it's even worse if you don't have the dlc. Other than stella's dungeon there's one more addition of character slot for battle and i guess that's nice for anyone who wants to see more imoutos on action. Everything else, gameplay wise, is pretty much the same.

Moving on, let's talk about technical problems, i've heard some people having crash and/or black screen problem but personally i've never encountered such problems. I don't know if it's already been fixed or not but still, if you're going to pick this up, take cautions. Another thing to note is that the optimization is worse compared to Rebirth 1. Everytime I broke the enemy guard, the framerate will drop from ~50fps to ~22fps though only for a brief period. It's not game breaking, but definitely jarring. General performance also feels worse, I got mostly around 50fps and that's with a GTX 970. In Rebirth 1 it's almost constant 60fps even when I was still using the older GTX 760. I'm not trying to be a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥ but the fact that Rebirth 1 doesn't have this problem at all is what baffles me considering both games are probably running on the exact same engine and assets.

Next, we have the story. To be honest, I think Nepgear just doesn't cut to be a protagonist. Don't get me wrong, I think she's cute, has okay personality, and great voice actors both for the japanese and the english version. I even liked her more compared to Neptune. But I think her personality is the problem. She's like...I don't know how to describe it accurately but I think it's righteous? Let's just say she's generally helping and a nice girl who admires her sister. I mean it's fine when she's the supporting character but when it's her as the main character it feels generic and doesn't match up with the series' tone.

And this is the part which I have the most problems about. Character interactions in the story is basically everyone talking about or with Nepgear, how nice she is, how mature she is, and all that thing. There's little interaction between everyone else, so much so that Nepgear is the only one that actually got character developments. All of that made worse by the repetitive bgm. Some bgm is just so overused that it lost the ability to emphasize the situation. It frustrates me so much when someone is sad or get motivated and I already know what kind of tune will be played. All that brought the end result that is a predictable and lifeless story.

And finally, the usual branching ending route. If you look at the achievements, there seems to be nine endings but it's actually just three endings that of normal, true, and conquest ending with leanbox, planeptune, lastation, lowee, and human ending just as some kind of prologue to the normal ending and holy sword ending being a slightly different version of true ending. Mind you, each nine ending has the share requirements that takes some grinding but the holy sword ending requires you to also have good lily ranks which will have you to grind even more. It's a tedious and boring process to get all of the endings. Adding to the fact that conquest ending is a really sad and dark one which is something unexpected for the franchise. I mean it's nice to have some twist to the story, even more so for a game with a catchy and playful tone like this one. It's just kinda unfair for Nepgear to be treated that way even if it's not the canon ending. In actuality I know this is not something to complain about. I was just kinda devastated when I saw the ending that's all.

To sum it up, I think Rebirth 2 is not a worthy successor to Rebirth 1. It's more grindy than already grindy Rebirth 1, it has technical problems that Rebirth 1 doesn't have, and the story is just...sad, both literally and figuratively. Even Nepgear got bullied in rebirth 3 for being a protagonist. If you're looking for more nepnep, I recommend to skip this one and go straight for Rebirth 3. It has some genuine improvements both from the technical, mechanical, and storytelling perspective and definitely my favorite one.

reviewText:
fps-issues across all specs at Guardbreak and HDD-transformations and unfortunately those are key elements in the game
game-breaking DLCs: you get a powerfull weapon that will easily carry you through the game and is only barely outclassed by the reward of a lvl 399 colosseum fight and with super EXP you can easily be level 99 at the end of chapter 2 (given if you do some farming)
the characters are pretty imbalanced and you will find yourself not using more than half of the cast since they are far worse (despite having their best gear) and/or provide nothing special
having an achievement dependant on a gimmick (Stella's Dungeon) in which you have little to no influence on the outcome (apart from chosing her equipment) is not good game design and using her DLC is highly recommended
the share juggling to get all the ending for each nation is tedious and neither fun nor challenging given that you only get an additional dialogue and an artwork. Same goes for Conquest/Holy Sword/True Ending and their Lily Rank juggling.
compared to Re;Birth 1 it is far too easy - even without the Weaken Enemies Plan. It is easily possible to beat a lvl 999 colosseum with a (roughly) lvl 850 party given you are properly equipped

Conclusion: Buy the game when its on sale with all the DLCs but dont spend more than 10€ on it. It has some strengths but the cons are just too overwhelming.

The best thing that came out of this was the conquest ending, but even that could have been done better and with more variety, like certain other concepts in this game that had great potential.

Overall, if you're expecting Re;birth 1 but better, than don't get this. Get this only if you want the CPU candidates to have the spotlight i guess...

reviewText:
How about we break another 4th Wall?

Ah, the second Neptunia game on steam... So similiar, yet with some minor differences.
I'll be honest, Re;birth 2 is very similiar to the first game of the franchise, the gameplay system
is pretty much the same. But on the other hand the main character cast gets flipped - main four this time around consists of 4 very  very  underraged girls.

The story is a tad more complex. Though it still retains it's sillyness with huge amounts of video game references and other fun stuff, this time around the game has more than 3 different endings.(While grinding for them may sadly feel like a chore, it can be worth it).
Graphics remain the same colourful anime-ish as before, and the Music/Sounds mostly remain the same as in the previous game with some additions.

And now to highlight the good and bad parts:

Pros
(?) Main characters are Loli (Cute and very young petite anime girls)
Slightly deeper, yet still light and fun story (More endings too)
While grinding is still here, it's not as gruelling. (the game is bundled with free DLC that
allows the player to more easily level-up if he wishes to do so.)
Similiary with farming, there are few ways in the game that allow easier farming such as
random encounter insta-kill.
The game's a JRPG with fun combat elements
Lily system - bonding with teammates now has a purpose (more or less) in this game!
Cons
The amount of items you can create is massive and will require multiple game completions
to fully create all of them. That also means spending time farming all the materials.
Rich story lovers may be dissapointed with the game's story, if they are looking for
something deep and strong.
Just like with the previous game, there are various monster and dungeon assets re-used.
Without researching online it's almost impossible to know how to get different endings
in the game, which some will want to do to fully beat the game.
A very similiar gameplay to the first HNRe;birth1.
To nitpick: The overworld background music is obnoxiously louder than all the other BGMs
which may cause serious hate against this particular one after long gameplay hours.
And also not all of the main character costumes were imported into this game. Kind of weird.
To summarise, Re;birth2 is certainly not a direct clone of the first game, but it is quite similiar in many aspects.
Even so, the fans of the franchise will certainly find something to love in this game. If you weren't turned-off by the game's bad points, or if you haven't experienced Neptunia before and want to start with  young  protagonists - by all means, try it out. Sadly, if a friend asked whether I'd recommend to play this as a sequel to Re;birth1, I would have to say - no. So bear that in mind when buying.

reviewText:
I really loved the 1st game. I hardly finish any game nowaday but I completly breezed through the 1st game in less than a week, Been a while since I had this much fun playing a game.

However this game disapointed me. To me it's not even a 2 it's basically a DLC of the first game because the battle system is literally the same... and battles are like 85% of the game. I loved the combat system but at the end of the 1st, the combat was getting old due to the fact that it's fairly easy, simple and repetitive. The battle system could've used some polishing but they didn't bother making any change at all.

Even though the story isn't the same and there's new characters, you will feel like you're redoing the same game over again. Maybe due to the fact that a lot of enemies are similar and even some dungeons are copied from the first game. The  guild / store / equipement are also the same for the most part and even the map feel like the same.

It feels lazy and rushed to be honest. I'm truly disapointed.

reviewText:
Finally. After hammering my way through HDNR;B1 over the past two weeks; I can play the second.

You should buy this if you played through the first one and thirst for more ridiculously funny dialogue, kawaii characters, in-depth story and meaty JRPG goodness.

Must say, though, there are huge CPU issues in both this and the original, where the game uses one core for most of the time. Every time I get a Guard Break, the FPS drops as one core gets ~80% usage, while the other three are doing nigh on nothing (0-20% load).

reviewText:
I see a lot of improvements from RE;BIRTH 1. Such as aesthetics, and some gameplay tweeks. I played re;birth one on vita and I have to say, I love the art. Looks so good at 1080p. I love how quick the menus are.

However, this port is poorly optimized. I've ran games such as Sonic Generations at max 1080p 60fps with no hiccups. That game has more texture detail and over all more going on with it thann this game.

This game chugs and becomes choppy consistantly.

I also am disappointed to see the continuation of re-used content. Dungeon layouts are copy pasted from the first game, and this game has several dungeons that are duplicates with different enemies.

The story once again is not deep or meaningful. It's a ligh hearted adventure with references and fanservice. If you are into that, cool. I'm pretty ok with it. COMPA BEST GIRL.

Battle system is still good, with the added 4th character it becomes very chaotic, in a good way.

It's an average game, I hear V-Generation is better so I'll get that sometime.

If you're into this type of game get it. I don't reccomend it. Poor optimization and very lazy level design. It's pretty much only worth getting on sale.

reviewText:
I was hesitating between DLCs for Re;Birth 1 or this. I bought this game because I thought I would rather enjoy a new story than grinding my way to lv.999. How wrong I was.

I have to say that the story sucks. It's more like watching kids arguing with each other. Boss battles are of the same pattern. They try to dramatize the plot, but that fails miserably so far.

The worst of all, these sisters are annoying. Nepgear lacks confidence and humor. Uni is downright irritating. She's a Tsundere like Noire, but wayyyy too much Tsundere on a not-cute side. Rom and Ram are, well, just a shy and a trolling kid. I was thinking about dropping the game half-way until CPUs were rescued. Suddenly, the game has some good ol' LoLs from Neptune and friends.

Now that I have Neptune, Noire, Vert, and Blanc back in the game, I guess I can pull through the end. But if you have played Re;Birth 1, I recommend you stay clear from this one. Just wait for Re;Birth 3 or do something else. Grinding to LV.999 in Re;Birth 1 might even be more enjoyable than this.

reviewText: I would love to be able to give this game a positive review. The previous game was amazing and I had huge hopes for this one. However, it crashes like crazy and the manual fixes are hit-or-miss at best. Consider yourself blessed if the game works for you at all without needing to fix the major crashes many of us are experiencing. The cutscenes are glitchy and the FPS is ridiculously unstable in dungeons and battles, jumping around randomly for no reason that I can discern. My computer more than meets the recommended requirements, yet it feels like I'm trying to run it on a low end laptop. This port was very lazily executed and I can't honestly recommend the game until it has had some work done, in which case I will gladly change my review. I think it's terrible that so many people are giving the game a positive review over trivial things like cute characters when that's only going to make the developers think not as much work will need to be done. They'd be far more likely to work on making it playable more quickly if the reviews actually reflected how playable the game is.

reviewText:
Keep the hate coming, mindless fanboys. It just shows that I'm right.

Why this game is overrated

- Half of the dungeons are low level copies of the original ones in Neptunia 1. Recycled maps would retain their quality with some differences here and there, but none of it remains here, and the rest are just no fun either. Some of them are plain painful to even look at.
- The Lowee Expo stage flatout looks like it was modeled after an industrial deep freeze storage room with only the pieces of meat missing from the ceiling. Just what kind of level designer would come up with something like that?
- Over half of the cast have no craftable outfits at all, which is just unacceptable. What's the point of having innumerable accessories if there's nothing to put them on with?
- Many of them fall short on damage later on from not having good equipment, and sometimes mechanic, which makes otherwise awesome EXE Drives worthless in Colosseum fights.
- Falcom's character redesign is just awful.
- Share juggling is a blatant waste of time, as acquiring the required amount at least eight times is incredibly tedious, and is only there for the sake of grinding, since the so called ending aren't really endings at all. They are only extra scenes at most and not very good ones at that, not explaining the time and effort demanded to see them.
- Conquest ending. Enough said.
- The whole story is not even close to what it was like in terms of entertainment to the previous installment.
- The music tracks which had a huge part in making the gameplay fun in Neptunia 1 was replaced with awful tracks, to the point where you wouldn't even notice if you turned it completely off.
- Red is so annoying, she should be an enemy, not a playable character.
- Stella's Dungeon is a nice minigame, but making something you have so little control of into an achivement is a messed up move, because even if it runs in the background, it takes days in itself to complete and that's if she succeeds in exploring on her first try. If not, you'll have to send her in until she does.
- Translation quality shows up again, taking quite some liberty at localizing the original text since you can understand at a glance that what the girls are saying and what you are reading are often very different. Sometimes entire lines get added or removed, which is anything but acceptable.

Why this game is fun

- Cave

As you can see, there are plenty of reasons not to buy this game at full price, only when it's on sale.

EDIT: Downvotes from fanboys and trolls don't mean anything to me if they won't even try to say why they didn't agree with me.

reviewText:
I haven't found a thing I to really enjoy in Hyper Dimension Neptunia aside from maybe the art.
For the time I've played, I watched scene after scene of tedious dialouge pertaining to some story that is a giant parody on the gaming industry. Then, I walk through some dungeon and fight a boss. I've done this about 15 times. Where I'm at in the game there still isn't any customization to do. There isn't really any dungeon exploring, you just go from A -> B, engaging enemies if you feel like it. The combat feels pointless and repetative. The quests are just kill enemy x number of time or collect x of this item.

I've liked games like Final Fantasy 1, 10, 12, Tactics Advanced, and Makai Kingdoms.

This game reminds me a lot of the Xenosaga series, which I didn't particularly like, but I don't remember Xenosaga being as terrible as Hyper Dimension Neptunia. And that is coming from someone who will acknowledge the cast cuteness/hotness of HDN > KOSMOS.

Maybe people would buy this game instead of torrenting it (and I wouldn't have to listen some passive aggressive story about torrenting) if the game actually had real redeaming qualities aside from anime jiggle. How on earth does this game have 94% positive reviews.

reviewText:
Alright, I'm just going to say this now. This game looks awesome. It looks grand, big, full of wonderfully made imagery and overall, a fun game to play, but it's just the technical aspects that really do my head it.
I'm a cut-scene kinda guy, and enjoy watching what goes on in between the gameplay, and the main problem for me is that it's stuttering is pretty bad. By that I mean, the audio continues while the video stops, they both stop momentarily and try to catch up to each other, and it's not just the cut-scenes. Even the opening credits has this problem! Throughout the 5 minutes I've played this, I've noticed this is a constant issue, and I hope it'll be addressed soon.
Just fix this one tiny problem, and I can get around to enjoying this game in whatever way I intend to.
Also, the voice acting is alright, but during the first fight scene, the actresses sound like they weren't putting much effort into it. The grunting sounds during the fight scenes sound half-♥♥♥♥♥, and when the girl notices her friends have been knocked out, she brings this point forth in a somewhat confused tone with some quick breath, rather then actual sadness and fear that her allies have fallen in battle, and now she's facing a demon by herself. I know you won't fix the voice, but next time, try and get your actors to emote more. That can impact the characters in a huge way if done right or wrong. Just a heads up.

reviewText:
I don't like JRPGs. I don't like visual novels.

This is a visual novel JRPG... thing. I love it. Why? The characters are relatable because you have to live through their struggles with them as your proxy. But why is the gameplay tolerable?

Well...

There's a sword in the DLC that totally destroys the progression curve in the game, and its ♥♥♥♥ing fantastic. No, seriously. I'm not kidding. I'm a gamer of two realms, one of action and one of story. I like multiplayer competitive games such as World of tanks, and story-driven games like Bioshock and System Shock 2. Grinding for hours and hours on end isn't something I have time for.

Very minor spoilers ahead, stuff you'll see in the first five minutes:

That DLC sword cut the entirety of the game's grindtastic feel out, made me feel like a baddass and I roleplayed (ACTUALLY ROLEPLAYED) as NepGear, the protagonist, being actually powerful enough to take on the big bad from the get-go, but she didn't have the confidence.

This actually plugs up a few plot holes, such as why NepGear was the only one to go with the other main CPU goddesses to fight the big bad in the first place. The very first cutscene in the game shows the main CPU characters being stomped into the dirt when you (probably) spent the entirety of the last game, which took me 50~ ish hours to complete. Most of that was boring slog grinding.

One has to assume that battle-hardened warriors wouldn't take a squishy newbie into such a critical battle, so therefore she must have been talented enough to risk taking her to the big bad fight. No, you can't say that it was for a numbers advantage, because they didn't take the other CPU canidates.

Its also worth noting that litteral goddesses should be able to outright crush low-level monsters and people with minimal effort, delegating other characters to support roles.

This is the first time I've ever seen DLC improve a game in such a profound manner.

10/10, would pay2win again.

reviewText:
It's a fun Final-Fantasy-like clone with cute loli's and pantsu. Also, occasional fanservice, yuri, ecchi and just general lewd jokes.
Look, the game is great. I love it. I recommend anyone who enjoys RPG's and anime to buy it.
Is the price fair? Probably not. It's a tad more expensive than I'd like it to be. It should be around 20€, maybe even as low as 15€. Why?

Alright, time to point out the game's flaws. (Or rather, Re;Birth1's flaws, since, I didn't buy the game, so I can't review Re;Birth1 here on steam. But! I digress. Re;Birth2 doesn't seem too obviously different it's predecessor, so, I'll base this review on my experience with that game. If I notice that the sequel is any different once I progress further, than I shall come at a later time and edit this review.)

Hyperdimension Neptunia (Which I will now begin calling HDN, or, jokingly, HDTuna for shortnening reasons) is, like I said, great. But I, on many instances, felt bored when playing it. Bored, and annoyed. Why?
First of all, the Information" system. Y'know
date: the one where you have to go to the map and either select the message pop-up on the map or select a world and read through every single bit of "information" everyone has to offer. Seems simple
recommended: right?\nWRONG.\nThere are people that give you items to alter the way dungeons work (The so-called Plans
hoursPlayed: and the remake system). And
voteText: at the beginning
helpfulPercent: it's all fun and simple
votesHelpful: the game is slow-paced
votesTotal: so
votesFunny: we're not encountering too many dungeons to which we could have those plans.\nThen you get to the late game. AKA
commentsCount: the "5 dungeons per story-related-action" area. And the "Here's 50 people offering NEW dungeons other than the story-related ones" area. Now
column16: you get 2 plans for each dungeon. One for changing the items in it
column17: the other for making enemies stronger. Let's multiply that 2 with the theoretical 15
column18: assuming I progressed a bit in the story without pauses. Now let's sum the result of that
column19: with the product of multiplying 50 with 2. So
column20:
(15*2)+(50*2)= 130.

One hundred and thirty.
One hundred and thirty people you have to talk to just to get that obnoxious "NEW!" message to stop appearing on every world.
One hundred and thirty LONGER-THAN-NEEDED chats with IRRELEVANT-TO-STORY characters.

But
column21: that isn't even my biggest peeve with HDTuna. From my experience in the first game
column22: enemies scale HORRIBLY. And I mean
column23: HORRIBLY\nI died on the second dungeon
column24: from a normal ghost enemy. And I had no idea that I would. After all
column25: I was pretty much gliding through the enemies in the first dungeon.\nThen we have the "semi-bosses". The orange icons you encounter on pretty much every area in the late-game. These guys should be easier than the main bosses in that area
column27: these guys are here basically just for me to grind
column28: right? WRONG!\nI have had to re-do half an hour worth of gameplay due to making the mistake that semi-bosses would be easier than the boss itself. I had already defeated the boss in the area
column29: and thought "Y'know what let's go ahead and defeat this dude. I'm sure after that boss
column30:
it won't be that hard."
It was.
It almost one-shot me after I did close to 0 damage to it due to it regenerating health every turn. And this is WITHOUT the "tough enemies" plan you can make after gathering certain items.

Speaking of making and gathering
column31: the remake system in the game is kind of extremely annoying. The ammount of items and dungeons and plans you can make/get
column34: and some even ask you for items you couldn't get until much later in the game
column35: when that ornament you wanted to make with said item is obsolete due to one you bought. It'd FEEL more worth it if the developers had let us known the actual stats and usages of the weapons/items/armour/et cetera. That way we'd know if the investment of time to grind for the items would be worth it. But instead we get what I can only describe as an unboxing simulator due to the nature of unknowing what we'll get.\n\nBut
column37: if you exclude the one or two times where the things I mentioned above actually HINDER you progress
column38: the game really is fun to play.\nIt had me actually laugh to one or two jokes the writers slipped in
column40: and the characters are adorable and lovable.\nFor the price I paid for it (14€ + an extra 1 or 2 € for the helpful
column41: but not needed AT ALL DLC)
column42: it's well worth your money. The trading cards alone made me my money back once I got foil cards on all the 4 drops (each card sold for 3€
column43: holy guacamole). For the full price?... Maybe not so much. If you want to give it a shot
column44: by all means.\n\nI give this game 4/5 tacos

reviewText:
Herm....If you're a fan of japanese animation/games or neptunia series why not give it a try?
Well, as you can see I'm a fan of both and I'll give you my honest review on the second HDN Re:B1rth 2.
There's not much change from the first one in term of gameplay but atleast you can add 1 more party member instead of 3 from the Re:B1rth 1.
There's also a minigame called Stella's Dungeon in it that helps you in a way (such as materials, gears, chips and etc.).
The surrounding areas and dungeon almost the same as the first one. The rules and craft and boss fight is also still the same.
What to be highlighted is there's a bug in the game that is sound and crash issue.
I can only help on 1 part that is the crash issue during starting the game, that is by not skipping until you were directed to the main page (new game, continue, dlc, option n etc.). I didn't across any other crashes other than the opening part.
As for another one is, sound problem. Supposely, all the dialog and event conversation, there should be voiced by the character. But, sometime it didn't work out as if its mute. In awhile its is back to normal, then it happens again.
Thus, for those who are kinda down about it, I advice don't worry about it. Its kinda normal for japanese game being christianed, and these kind of problems occurs. Sooner or later, there's gonna be a patch for it and yes it is still new on Steam. So, you don't need to be regret once you bought it on SALE. Just get it while you can.

reviewText:
Good golly gosh, prepare yourself for more Hyperdimension Neptunia action! Only this time taking center stage are the CPUs sisters. The game is very charming in that it doesn't take itself to seriously (the only real exception being one of the endings). Despite the name Re;Birth2 you don't really need to play Re;Birth1 to fully understand whats going on. Many of the features in both games are the same and as far as plot goes they don't really meet up with one another very much.

Protip: If you're an Otaku looking for anime waifu material then look no further.

Pros:
Like the first game this one also has a fair bit of spoken dialog. Not as much as the first one but it's there mostly for storyline cutscenes and even then not all of them. I find it to be a fair amount though
The system the game uses to get items, change items that spawn, and change dungeons is incredibly easy to use (albeit a bit grindy)
Endings, so many endings maybe too many endings, not all of the endings are happy ;_;
Cons:
Button mapping, I learned to get used to this, but the controls took a bit to get used to just like the first game. It's a small quarel.
Grinding. If you're going for all of the achievements, you're likely going to be playing this for 100+ hours leveling up, getting money in game, getting all the different endings. I don't particularly mind this as JRPGs consume every single fiber of my being and control my life but it might be a deciding factor for some people.

The so-and-so: The DLC for this game will make Nepgear INCREDIBLY overpowered to the point where most battles arent even a challenge until about 75% through the game. I strongly recommend that if you plan on taking this game on and you want to experience it as it is made, then avoid using the DLC weapons. That being said, if you want an easy mode or you're just looking to see what exactly the Neptunia games are all about then by all means go for it. I won't judge you.

Final Thoughts: Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth2: SIsters Generation has its quirks when compared to the first game. That wouldn't stop me from recommending this, but I would recommend the first one before this one not because its the first in the series, but because it felt more fleshed out as a game.

10/10 Nepgear is best sister.

reviewText:
Loli versions of the CPU's makes this an instant win.

A cute game and has a simple playstyle. This game turns to the CPU candidates as your main characters.  It is about 60% dialogue, 40% playing. Nothing new from the first Neptunia but those starting their Neptunia journey with this one should be aware it is a visual novel / turn based game mix. It contains a bunch of comedy and parodies throughout. It is fun while it lasts and enjoyable to an anime fan so if you liked the first, get this one. There is not a lot to this game to point out for positive points because it has two simple concepts and a basic story, nothing unique aside from the anime game style. It is good and you are either a fan of Neptunia series or aren't.

This one is Shorter than the first and has only half the dungeons approximately howerver. Those who liked the CPU's may feel unhappy if they can't appreciate the younger sisters taking the lead. The game feels a lot easier than the first was with much less grind time needed. It seems like there was a lack of thought as a large chunk of the game turns out to be fighting the same person over and over and over.......This becomes quite dissapointing as there really is no creativity or much change to the battles aside from extra stats. Balance becomes questionable at points where you fight one battle with little difficulty then the follow-up is hard and losing means having potentially wasted 20+ mins on the previous fight.

The character Red" is rather annoying and her constantly talking about wifeys would have been best left out of the game. As mentioned in the review for the first Neptunia
date:
trying to push same gender stuff heavily into peoples faces is a really poor choice. This type of material should be left minimal as 75% of people are not truely supportive of such concepts. It would be fine had it been mentioned maybe 2-3 times but it is really pushing it pointing it out at least 30+ times and that being the main dialogue she constantly throws into the game.

Personal experience score: 7.5/10

Story: 8/10 - Pretty standard. Amusing and works for the series but nothing brand new.
Sound: 10/10 - Nice soundtrack actually. LAN Castle dungeon is the most epic
Graphics: 7.5/10 - Decent for an anime game. Could be more detailed and looking less like it was made in the 2000's but it has its charm and fits fine.
Controls: 10/10 - Nothing out of place here
recommended: hardest control aspect may be trying to maximize mobs within an attack zone radius
hoursPlayed: especially for ranged weapons.\nGame Length: 7/10 - For a single play through with doing some collection
voteText: it will be about 20 hours. There are additional dungeons in NG+ though and the 2nd play through will most likely be where you go for the different endings which means at least 40 hours. A lack of dungeons compared to the first though is where the problem lies."

reviewText:
Just going to say this review is gonna be filled with some mixed messages.

I've only recently stumbled into the series after a mishap with gifting gone wrong with ReBirth 1 and I wound up mostly enjoying that game. The combat is fun, I like the game / industry humor but not so much the fan service. It's kinda like Disgaea but with a more ..'kawaii' wrapping and without the large panel based map battles.

What I like:
It's more of the same but expanded, dungeons are larger to explore, there's more variety to character moves and more characters in general. The game keeps what was good but improves upon the first in terms of gameplay. The new characters reflect the companies they spoof well, Cave being a very amusing one who represents a company who makes bullet hell shooters...and her specials all reflect this. There's also a lot more characters and more focus on the non-CPU (transforming) characters.

The combat is fun, more so with a 4th character in battle allowing you to feel less cramped with battle options. Feels like you're more able to dishout damage while having 1 character handle support.

What I don't like:
The game takes on a more darker tone from the get go, which loses a lot of impact when you find this is NOT the same universe at all. Shortly after the start a character recounts how she met Neptune and ...that's not how it happened. So this game has absolutely nothing to do with 1 story wise. Yes you still care for the characters but you have to wonder why they'd spin off in a series of games that already has (at the time of writing) 4 spin off titles on the Vita. There's more 'fanservice' which is less appealing because if you happen to look at the screens ...you'll notice there's 2 very young girls and they aren't shy with pushing some really dumb perversion with them.

They reuse a lot, I mean a bloody lot. Some music, characters & moves, the animated portraits, some maps are straight up lifted from the first game. There are new maps but you'll be starting a dungeon and hey, you were here in 1!
I'm currently on chapter 3 and it's been very repititious, the same Underling character getting in the way and getting away. It feels like they dumped their efforts into the new characters vs adding interesting enemies. Maybe this changes later.
3 chapters in and I really feel like I've done nothing because you just don't stop this 1 dumb character, or it's subordiantes. Near the end of it someone else FINALLY drops in.

Currently the game is bugged too, the world map music is unbearably loud and the rest of the music despite being jacked up well above the other sounds is too low. Which is a shame since the music is fun.

I'm not saying this is a bad game, though I do seem to have more complaints than praise. I do like the first game better in ways...kinda like how Disgaea 1 had better story and characters and Disgaea 2 had superior gameplay, this is a lot like that. But if this game seems a bit wonky and you're interested in the new one coming out, Neptunia Victory...I wouldn't blame you for skipping this one since as I've stated it has nothing to do with the story of 1, maybe not Victory either.

reviewText:
Herm....If you're a fan of japanese animation/games or neptunia series why not give it a try?
Well, as you can see I'm a fan of both and I'll give you my honest review on the second HDN Re:B1rth 2.
There's not much change from the first one in term of gameplay but atleast you can add 1 more party member instead of 3 from the Re:B1rth 1.
There's also a minigame called Stella's Dungeon in it that helps you in a way (such as materials, gears, chips and etc.).
The surrounding areas and dungeon almost the same as the first one. The rules and craft and boss fight is also still the same.
What to be highlighted is there's a bug in the game that is sound and crash issue.
I can only help on 1 part that is the crash issue during starting the game, that is by not skipping until you were directed to the main page (new game, continue, dlc, option n etc.). I didn't across any other crashes other than the opening part.
As for another one is, sound problem. Supposely, all the dialog and event conversation, there should be voiced by the character. But, sometime it didn't work out as if its mute. In awhile its is back to normal, then it happens again.
Thus, for those who are kinda down about it, I advice don't worry about it. Its kinda normal for japanese game being christianed, and these kind of problems occurs. Sooner or later, there's gonna be a patch for it and yes it is still new on Steam. So, you don't need to be regret once you bought it on SALE. Just get it while you can.

reviewText:
An adorable harem of beauties and cuties saves the world from evil, what's not to like? As a fan of fantasy games, and turn-based RPG combat in general, this pretty much ticks all the boxes for me. Gameindustri is under attack from an evil organization bent on destruction (aren't they always), and they've beaten the mightiest heroes -- the CPU's already. Cue the CPU candidates -- the younger siblings of the rulers of Gameindustri.

Wonderfully voiced characters take you on a more freeform journey across Gameindustri, with places to explore and items to be found. The crafting system let's you make everything from items to 'plans' which can add enemies to dungeons, change the items therein, or even unlock new dungeons. At it's heart is the combat, which is fun and, at times, quite funny. You haven't lived until you've beaten a monster half to death with a yoyo and some maracas!

If you like JRPG's, you'll absolutely love this one. There's tons to find and do.

reviewText:
It's neptunia, I can't not recommend this.

MK2 was my entry to the series so I was pretty hyped for this remake of it and by all accounts it's a pretty good game through some parts of the story feel a bit watered down compared to the original(MK2), mainly some parts of the dialogue that feel a bit rushed but it's hardly noticable.

The gameplay is pretty good and feels more smoother compared to rebirth 1 and like the last game there is tons of replay value to find here, multiple endings, unlockable party members, crafting, you name it.

As always we have a wonderful cast of characters and the CPU candidates are an interesting bunch who get fleshed out over the course of the game.

Unlike the first one, the story here is more serious in parts, while still maintaining it's light hearted moments and trademark humour.

It's a good game and if you are a fan of the series you will want to pick this up. Or if you just like JRPGs in general then give this a shot.

reviewText:
Another very good game in this series.

Let's do the good first.

If you played Re;Birth1 you already know how to play this and can easily jump right in. Jump I have not found a use for yet aside from just wanting to make your character bounce in the air... or panty shots, if you're into that. Combat is fairly fluid and easy to learn, and you get new skills at a fairly regular pace. There are 3 different types of attacks, Rush, Power, and Break. Rush fills the EXE gauge, Power does more health damage, and Break does more guard damage. That along with 4 elemental properties, statuses, and being either physical or magic makes for a rather interesting mix for combat. You also have a reserve character slot for each character in your party, which you can swap out to if the party member is alive.

Graphics are nice, not the best but definitely good for an anime style game. Some of the areas and characters look amazing, and some EXE attacks are just beautiful to watch. Music and sound effects are good, nothing you will remember, but fitting for the atmosphere of the areas or what you are doing. Voice acting is pretty decent, with most of the characters having well written, if sometimes cheesy as all hell, dialogue. There is also plenty of tongue in cheek humor and breaking of the 4th wall simply for the fun of it. Various enemies are reused over and over, with only palette swaps to really mark the difference in how they look, but that is standard for many RPGs.

There are a ton of playable characters. I have 13 right now and I am fairly certain there's at least another 7. Party size is 4 characters, with another 4 in reserve. Thankfully ALL characters that are alive get XP, regardless of if they're in the party or not.

Stella's Dungeon is a very nice little addition to this game, even if you do not control Stella directly it is entertaining to do. Equip her gear, send her on her way, and do whatever until she is beaten or comes back with loot.

Now the bad...

This game is almost a direct clone of Re;Birth1, if you did not like 1, you are not going to like this. Combat, a list of characters, and various other things are all the same, and if you played the first one you are going to be going haven't I done this before" every now and then.

I mentioned the large amount of characters earlier
date: if you plan to keep them all up to date on gear you are going to be spending an obscene amount of currency. Another slight issue is with so many characters many will level up at the same time
recommended: and wanting to keep their combo abilities and finishers up to date can be annoying when 5+ characters all get new abilities after a single fight.\n\nIt is incredibly easy to overlevel your characters. And I mean insanely easy. I have not farmed for money or XP
hoursPlayed: just items now and then to finish off quests (quests give currency and items
voteText: not XP). I just got a new character and my characters are a good 12-15 levels above her. It should be noted you can use the plan system to weaken of strengthen the enemies.\n\nThat being said the story is different
helpfulPercent: there are new characters
votesHelpful: new enemies
votesTotal: and I would buy it again."

reviewText:
First thing to note is that Rebirth 2 is not in the same dimension as Rebirth 1, thus does not follow the story. I want to believe, from what I remember, that I prefer the story from R1 over R2. That said, I don't mean that R2 is bad, it was fun and just as enjoyable as the first one.

Both games are pretty much the same deal with a different story and a few different elements. The main difference between R1 and R2 is that R2 has A LOT of endings and a mini game called Stella's Dungeon.

For whatever reason, Stella's Dungeon ended up being the thing I liked the most about R2. I enjoyed opening my game, looking at her loot, then sending her back on an adventure before resuming whatever I was doing previously.

reviewText:
Lots and lots of scantily clad anime girls populate this game. It's a ton of grindy, JRPG fun, with a very good battle system. The dialogue very often shatters the 4th wall, and is very self-aware. It's really easy to get attached to the various characters in the game, and I honestly finally understand the phrase 'waifu.' (Nepgear forever!)

That said, there are a few flaws in the game. The Stellas Dungeon mini game is... Kind of obnoxious, in that it utilizes the timer mechanic that is so popular in mobile F2P games. The graphics are very good, especially the characters, but the dungeons are mostly flat and lacking in a lot of detail.

I love the Hyperdimension Neptunia games, and so far, Sisters Generation is my favourite of the series.

reviewText:
I would say that this game is neither better nor worse than the first one. It has its own pluses and minuses. Here's what I thought they were:

PROS:
+ 4 people in the party now! That was really exciting for me, cause in Re;Birth1 I always wanted to have all 4 CPUs, as well as the candidates, in one battle but that was never possible. Now it was, and I thought that was a nice addition.
+ I liked that the dungeons weren't all recycled versions of the dungeons we saw in the first game. Some look similar to those but most of them were new designs. Even the 4 cities were redesigned, and I think they look way cooler.
+ Plenty of different endings and outcomes to add to the replayability value. One of the endings in particular, the Conquest Ending, was DARK AS HELL. I mean holy crap, I've seen bad endings in video games before but this one was like, really intense. Not even Nep's humor was able to soften it for me.
+ Stella's Dungeon was a nice new feature as well. You're able to send Stella off to dungeons to find items while you continue on with the game.
+ Just like in Re;Birth1 with the sisters, you can bring in the Oracles of each city into the game to join your party. I haven't done that but I'm working on it. The requirements are pretty high, but I'm determined. They have very cool designs.
+ I guess I should put that there's a lot more boobage in the game. I mean it's not really my cuppa tea, but y'know. For all you pervs out there, I'm sure you'll be happy to know that the game wastes no time in shoving everything in your face, so to speak.

CONS:
- Besides the extra person in the party, there's really no new additions to the combat at all.
- Less customizability was something I noticed. The outfit selection in particular was a lot more limited. In Re;Birth1, there were a ♥♥♥♥ ton of outfits in the shop. Now, though, they seem much fewer.
- Not enough Nep-Nep! I don't know about you guys, but Nepgear was such an underwhelming heroine to me. She's just so... I don't know. I mean she's likeable and all, but she doesn't have as big of a presence as Neptune did. I was gleeful when Nep-Nep finally appeared and started talking, but it wasn't enough. :c I know Nepgear was supposed to be the star of this game but she didn't feel like one at all. I just kept waiting for Nep-Nep to appear. If you're a huge fan of Neptune herself, then I'm sorry to say she's not in this game much at all.
- This is sorta tied with the not enough Nep-Nep thing. The game has much less funny moments or humor at all. Besides Neptune, Red is pretty much the only FUNNY character in my opinion. Besides that, the plot itself isn't all that engaging. Not that the first game's plot was amazing or anything, but y'know, at least it was fun to sit through due to the character interactions. In this one the characters are just meh, I think. Nepgear especially.

Overall there are many things they could've done to make this much better than the first game, as a sequel should be, but I'm still pretty happy with it and having a blast playing it so far, so I definitely recommend it despite its flaws. Plus, I saw several trailers for Re;Birth3 and it seems like they're renewing a lot of the features with that game, so I'm pretty excited!

reviewText:
First off, I'd like to say that I have not played Rebirth 1, so I cannot compare these two games in the review.

The game is a light-hearted RPG with various references to gaming and anime tidbits. The storyline is nothing major, nothing dramatic/crazy, but entertaining and somewhat heartwarming. With this story comes multiple endings too.
+ The gameplay itself is great, variety of combos and skills, making battles not feel repetitive.
+ Amazing humor and references
+ The use of plans makes the game feel very different everytime, through changing a dungeon's content, to changing the difficulty of the game itself.
+ Large amounts of characters to experiment with

- Game doesn't seem well optimised for the PC
- The game feels grindy at some points, not so much with levels, but some other stuff (Shares for example).

+- This doesn't fit into a pro nor a con, but the game was obviously designed for handheld, so expect small dungeons, nothing crazy large.

Game is great! Enjoyed it very much, and will continue to enjoy until I near 100% this game.

reviewText:
An adorable harem of beauties and cuties saves the world from evil, what's not to like? As a fan of fantasy games, and turn-based RPG combat in general, this pretty much ticks all the boxes for me. Gameindustri is under attack from an evil organization bent on destruction (aren't they always), and they've beaten the mightiest heroes -- the CPU's already. Cue the CPU candidates -- the younger siblings of the rulers of Gameindustri.

Wonderfully voiced characters take you on a more freeform journey across Gameindustri, with places to explore and items to be found. The crafting system let's you make everything from items to 'plans' which can add enemies to dungeons, change the items therein, or even unlock new dungeons. At it's heart is the combat, which is fun and, at times, quite funny. You haven't lived until you've beaten a monster half to death with a yoyo and some maracas!

If you like JRPG's, you'll absolutely love this one. There's tons to find and do.

reviewText:
Neptunia Rebirth2, the second installment as a remake for Neptunia Mk2.

EDIT: My major qualm for this is the translation/localization. Whoever come up with those scripts, fire that guy. Super crappy translation. If you knew enough Nihonggo, you'll get by without reading the script but for the others who don't, it obscures the message as well as the personality of the character(s).

Story-wise, completely unrelated to Rebirth1 as they say it happens in a different dimension (well that explains why it is called Hyperdimension per se). Though I kind of understand why they did it since it doesn't make sense to have powered-up imoutos when your onee-sans are strong enough to deal with issues (ala Rebirth1). They need to rewrite it so that the sisters would become the core in the game.

Game play is the same as Rebirth1 with inclusion of another party member. Not sure why they added another slot since I didn't feel underpowered when there just 3 in a party in Rebirth1 but hey at least you could now roll-out with 4 CPUs at the same time. Word of advice, just put off the DLC weapons if you want a more genuine experience during battles in your first playthrough.

Endings, with the emphasis on the 's'. We now have multiple endings depending on the conditions you've met while playing instead of just normal and true in Rebirth1. It requires share manipulation and lily rank levels which IMO is okay. Same goes with unlockable characters as well. Some people are usually put off with the 'amount' of work you need to accomplish this but IMO that is part of the game. You want something, you work for it. You want the game to hold your hand and be spoon-fed, look elsewhere. Anyway, once you get the gist of it, you'll start preparations to adjust the shares early in the game to get your desired outcome. Multiple playthroughs are encouraged but not required.

Issues.. we'll I occasionally encounter crashes especially when entering dungeons before but I managed to deal with it by setting the compatibility to Windows XP.

reviewText:
First thing to note is that Rebirth 2 is not in the same dimension as Rebirth 1, thus does not follow the story. I want to believe, from what I remember, that I prefer the story from R1 over R2. That said, I don't mean that R2 is bad, it was fun and just as enjoyable as the first one.

Both games are pretty much the same deal with a different story and a few different elements. The main difference between R1 and R2 is that R2 has A LOT of endings and a mini game called Stella's Dungeon.

For whatever reason, Stella's Dungeon ended up being the thing I liked the most about R2. I enjoyed opening my game, looking at her loot, then sending her back on an adventure before resuming whatever I was doing previously.

reviewText: Ok, IF and Compile Heart have hit on something for me. I have 2 games out of my 600+ where I have completed 100% of steam achievements. One is this, the other is Agarest 2.\n\nOn to the review. I loved rebirth 1, and although I read some reviews saying this wasn;t as good, I;m glad I tried it. reviewText:
-WARNING: THIS GAME MAY HAVE GAMEBREAKING PERFORMANCE ISSUES FOR YOUR MACHINE. RESEARCH ACCORDINGLY BEFORE PURCHASING-

The sequel to Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth1, but this time with Nepgear, Sister and Sister candidate to Neptune, as the protagonist.  The mechanics are very similar to the original game, but are different enough to feel fresh. Many characters that were included in Re;birth1 are back, along with several new characters.

Pros
Lots of improvements over the original, and you can still have a personal army of waifus.


-Loads of new characters, while still keeping (most) of the originals. (21+ characters if all are unlocked)

-More (English) voice acting than the original

-For most characters, voice acting quality is good (You will know the bad ones)

-More endings than the original

-Dungeon plans are simpler than the original (Original has giant webs of plans that make missing certain events easy.)

-Combat is very similar to the original, but provides enough to feel fresh

-Progression difficulty spikes are toned down a bit (In the original, you'd often have the grind heavily to fight the next boss, notably (Spoilers) Black Heart around chapter 2
.
-Story is trying to be a bit more serious, and even side characters are given a bit more lore

-4 characters to a party opens up a lot more strategies

-Dungeons feel larger, and the change dungeon plans give a lot more depth

-You find interesting items more often (original often gave boring items from treasures)

-Quest rewards are more interesting.

-You can gain little extra rewards through the use of Stella's Dungeon"
recommended:
except for performance problems. I'm mostly listing little pet peeves.


-PERFORMANCE PROBLEMS

-Odd technical glitches (World Map volume is incredibly loud for example)

-While most of the voice acting is good

reviewerDisplayName: Guns don't kill people, LAGS do
reviewText:
Like a sequel granted with its expectations, Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth2: Sisters Generation lives up it's name  by giving us more lore, more content, more endings than its older sister counterpart.

Being more shy and diligent than her older sister, Re;birth 2 brings a more serious story comparing to the adventure hero archetype of the first series. There are more Chirper Events, more systematic built, more progressive than the first game, but in the end, both games have the same line of heroic quest, saving Gamindustri. (Btw, you get to have 4 people on the field at the same time. 4 People, how cool is that!?)

However, contrasting its older sister, there is a bad ending, (although you will not encounter it simply) and we need to replay the game at least once (and work harder) to experience the full extent of the contents the game brings. Some research or experiments may be needed to fulfill this requirement, simply playing the game wasn't enough.

The only thing that doesn't fit in is that the Chirper Events occur doesn't match the hassle and busy mood the game proposed. Other than that, there are too many Chirper Events piling up on a certain point that we may get tired of reading it through. Blanc, Vert and Rom might enjoy this, but I'm pretty sure NepNep & Ram doesn't, since they prefer to smash and bust the concrete of those buildings with evil intentions.

Comparing to the first game, some of the map designs were unoriginal. But most of it feels like having its own backstory from its design, like epic, ya know. It's maps were more structured than the first game.

Music is a blast! (If you aren't comparing with the first game, mood is different, less action, more atmospheric) The music were refined as if it was designed for an older action gamer audience, its composed of more structured roots than its randomness.

Characters design and progression were original, pretty well set and preserved from the first game. Nothing much to say here other than the game adds more beloved characters to vanquish the monsters with!

This review may sound critical, but the game is awesome as much as the first game, like sisters, both have different sets of cognition, and I love both of them. (But NepNep is still the best.) If you enjoy the first series and gameplay style, you will truly enjoy the second.


However, this game lives in a parallel universe from the first game. And comparing to the first series, this game has more fanservice. Good or bad, you decide.

reviewText:
I have to say I was dissapointed by the game.  I went into this game knowing that the gameplay wasn't going to change much.  And I was right a few things were tweaked like the stats on humans which were garbage in Nep1.  But the one thing that really did me in was that the story was laking.

The story didn't feel as fun as it did in the first largly due to the fact that Neptune isn't a big part of it.  Instead of giving the other characters some spotlight they instead introduced a new character.  It was very obvious RED was only made to replace Neptune and recreate the chaos that was Neptune. There was also a lot of useless text.  More than the first. I found myself skipping story text because it was so repetitive and boring.

The gameplay is still fun. Again humans are actually pretty useful in this game they have a lot of aoe spells but with the draw back of not having HDD and gaining some temporary stats.  There are now 4 slots for your team which makes room for a lot more strategies but it seems like the enemies have gotten tougher too.  Big enemies take a lot more damage to kill. As for pretty much everything else its the same.

This game is fun but the story was just too bland and boring for me.

**Not to mention the not-so-obvious requirements to even progress past the normal ending.  Rebirth1 never had that issue. If you got the normal ending in Reirth1 you just missed out on some different cutscenes and artwork.  In Rebirth2 you miss out on 2 full chapters including new dungeons, plans and story.  In retrospective that's like 20% of the game.
